definitions.definition: as appears or is stated to be true, though not necessarily so; apparently.
definitions.example: the party secretary resigned, ostensibly from ill health

words.origin: mid 16th century (in myriad (sense 2 of the noun)): via late Latin from Greek murias, muriad-, from murioi ‘10,000’.

definitions.definition: a countless or extremely great number of people or things.
definitions.example: myriads of insects danced around the light above my head

definitions.definition: (chiefly in classical history) a unit of ten thousand.
definitions.example: the army was organized on a decimal system, up to divisions of 10,000 or myriads

definitions.definition: countless or extremely great in number.
definitions.example: he gazed at the myriad lights of the city

words.origin: mid 16th century (in egregious (sense 2)): from Latin egregius ‘illustrious’, literally ‘standing out from the flock’, from ex- ‘out’ + grex, greg- ‘flock’. Sense 1 (late 16th century) probably arose as an ironic use.

definitions.definition: outstandingly bad; shocking.
definitions.example: egregious abuses of copyright

definitions.definition: remarkably good.

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin erroneus (from erro(n- ) ‘vagabond’, from errare ‘to stray, err’) + -ous.

definitions.definition: wrong; incorrect.
definitions.example: employers sometimes make erroneous assumptions

words.origin: Middle English (formerly also as ingender ): from Old French engendrer, from Latin ingenerare, from in- ‘in’ + generare ‘beget’ (see generate).

definitions.definition: cause or give rise to (a feeling, situation, or condition).
definitions.example: the issue engendered continuing controversy

words.origin: late Middle English (formerly also as imploy ): from Old French employer, based on Latin implicari ‘be involved in or attached to’, passive form of implicare (see imply). In the 16th and 17th century the word also had the senses ‘enfold, entangle’ and ‘imply’, derived directly from Latin; compare with implicate.

definitions.definition: give work to (someone) and pay them for it.
definitions.example: the firm employs 150 people

definitions.definition: make use of.
definitions.example: the methods they have employed to collect the data

words.origin: mid 16th century (as a heraldic term): from Latin salient- ‘leaping’, from the verb salire . The noun dates from the early 19th century.

definitions.definition: most noticeable or important.
definitions.example: it succinctly covered all the salient points of the case

definitions.definition: (of an angle) pointing outwards.
(of an animal) standing on its hind legs with the forepaws raised, as if leaping.
a piece of land or section of fortification that juts out to form an angle.

words.origin: early 19th century (in the sense ‘stimulate by electricity’): from French galvaniser (see Galvani, Luigi).

definitions.definition: shock or excite (someone) into taking action.
definitions.example: the urgency of his voice galvanized them into action
synonyms: give someone a shot in the arm

definitions.definition: coat (iron or steel) with a protective layer of zinc.
definitions.example: they promised they would galvanize the iron railings to prevent rusting

definitions.definition: galvanized steel sheeting, typically as used for roofing or fencing.
definitions.example: the rain was beating hard against Miss Orilie's galvanize

words.origin: mid 17th century: from medieval Latin substantiat- ‘given substance’, from the verb substantiare .

definitions.definition: provide evidence to support or prove the truth of.
definitions.example: they had found nothing to substantiate the allegations

words.origin: late Middle English: via Latin from Greek kaustikos, from kaustos ‘combustible’, from kaiein ‘to burn’.

definitions.definition: able to burn or corrode organic tissue by chemical action.
definitions.example: a caustic cleaner

definitions.definition: sarcastic in a scathing and bitter way.
definitions.example: the players were making caustic comments about the refereeing

definitions.definition: formed by the intersection of reflected or refracted parallel rays from a curved surface.
a caustic substance.
a caustic surface or curve.

words.origin: mid 16th century: from late Latin elucidat- ‘made clear’, from the verb elucidare, from e- (variant of ex- ) ‘out’ + lucidus ‘lucid’.

definitions.definition: make (something) clear; explain.
definitions.example: work such as theirs will help to elucidate this matter

words.origin: mid 17th century: from Greek esōterikos, from esōterō, comparative of esō ‘within’, from es, eis ‘into’. Compare with exoteric.

definitions.definition: intended for or likely to be understood by only a small number of people with a specialized knowledge or interest.
definitions.example: esoteric philosophical debates

words.origin: late 16th century: formed irregularly from Latin tenuis ‘thin’ + -ous.

definitions.definition: very weak or slight.
definitions.example: the tenuous link between interest rates and investment

words.origin: late 16th century: from late Latin perfunctorius ‘careless’, from Latin perfunct- ‘done with, discharged’, from the verb perfungi .

definitions.definition: (of an action) carried out without real interest, feeling, or effort.
definitions.example: he gave a perfunctory nod

words.origin: late 16th century: via Latin from Greek anōmalia, from anōmalos (see anomalous).

definitions.definition: something that deviates from what is standard, normal, or expected.
definitions.example: there are a number of anomalies in the present system

definitions.definition: the angular distance of a planet or satellite from its last perihelion or perigee.

words.origin: early 17th century: from French facette, diminutive of face ‘face, side’ (see face).

definitions.definition: one side of something many-sided, especially of a cut gem.
definitions.example: a blue and green jewel that shines from a million facets

definitions.definition: a particular aspect or feature of something.
definitions.example: a philosophy that extends to all facets of the business

definitions.definition: any of the individual units (ommatidia) that make up the compound eye of an insect or crustacean.

words.origin: mid 16th century (in the medical sense): via late Latin from Greek plēthōrē, from plēthein ‘be full’.

definitions.definition: a large or excessive amount of something.
definitions.example: a plethora of committees and subcommittees

definitions.definition: an excess of a bodily fluid, particularly blood.

words.origin: mid 19th century: from modern Latin ubiquitas (from Latin ubique ‘everywhere’, from ubi ‘where’) + -ous.

definitions.definition: present, appearing, or found everywhere.
definitions.example: his ubiquitous influence was felt by all the family

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin opinari ‘think, believe’.

definitions.definition: hold and state as one's opinion.
definitions.example: ‘The man is a genius,’ he opined

words.origin: late Middle English: from Old French or from Latin antecedent- ‘going before’, from antecedere, from ante ‘before’ + cedere ‘go’.

definitions.definition: a thing that existed before or logically precedes another.
definitions.example: some antecedents to the African novel might exist in Africa's oral traditions

definitions.definition: a person's ancestors or family and social background.
definitions.example: her early life and antecedents have been traced

definitions.definition: an earlier word, phrase, or clause to which another word (especially a following relative pronoun) refers back.
the statement contained in the ‘if’ clause of a conditional proposition.
preceding in time or order; previous or pre-existing.
definitions.example: antecedent events

definitions.definition: denoting or counting as an antecedent.

words.origin: mid 16th century: from French, from Italian bastione, from bastire ‘build’.

definitions.definition: a projecting part of a fortification built at an angle to the line of a wall, so as to allow defensive fire in several directions.
an institution, place, or person strongly maintaining particular principles, attitudes, or activities.
definitions.example: cricket's last bastion of discrimination

definitions.definition: the leading sheep of a flock, with a bell on its neck.

words.origin: Middle English: from Old French bourgeonner ‘put out buds’, from borjon ‘bud’, based on late Latin burra ‘wool’.

definitions.definition: begin to grow or increase rapidly; flourish.
definitions.example: the city's suburbs have burgeoned, sprawling out from the centre

definitions.definition: a bud or young shoot.

words.origin: early 20th century: from catalysis, on the pattern of analyst .

definitions.definition: a substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without itself undergoing any permanent chemical change.
definitions.example: chlorine acts as a catalyst promoting the breakdown of ozone

words.origin: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘deceased’): from Latin defunctus ‘dead’, past participle of defungi ‘carry out, finish’, from de- (expressing reversal) + fungi ‘perform’.

definitions.definition: no longer existing or functioning.
definitions.example: the now defunct Somerset & Dorset railway line

definitions.definition: (of an attitude, habit, or belief) firmly established and difficult or unlikely to change; ingrained.
definitions.example: an entrenched resistance to change

words.origin: Old English fōstrian  ‘feed, nourish’, from fōster ‘food, nourishment’, of Germanic origin; related to food. The sense ‘bring up another's (originally also one's own) child’ dates from Middle English. See also foster-.

definitions.definition: encourage the development of (something, especially something desirable).
definitions.example: the teacher's task is to foster learning

definitions.definition: bring up (a child that is not one's own by birth).
definitions.example: a person who would foster Holly was found

words.origin: mid 17th century: from Latin, ‘assault, force’, from impetere ‘assail’, from in- ‘towards’ + petere ‘seek’.

definitions.definition: the force or energy with which a body moves.
definitions.example: hit the booster coil before the flywheel loses all its impetus

words.origin: mid 17th century (earlier (late Middle English) as inadvertence ): from in-1 ‘not’ + Latin advertent- ‘turning the mind to’ (from the verb advertere ).

definitions.definition: not resulting from or achieved through deliberate planning.
definitions.example: an inadvertent administrative error occurred that resulted in an overpayment

words.origin: late Middle English: via Old French from late Latin incessant-, from in- ‘not’ + Latin cessant- ‘ceasing’ (from the verb cessare ).

definitions.definition: (of something regarded as unpleasant) continuing without pause or interruption.
definitions.example: the incessant beat of the music

words.origin: Middle English enflaume, inflaume, from Old French enflammer, from Latin inflammare, from in- ‘into’ + flamma ‘flame’.

definitions.definition: provoke or intensify (strong feelings, especially anger) in someone.
definitions.example: high fines further inflamed public feelings

definitions.definition: cause inflammation in (a part of the body).
definitions.example: the finger joints were inflamed with rheumatoid arthritis

definitions.definition: light up with or as if with flames.
definitions.example: the torches inflame the night to the eastward

words.origin: late Middle English (in instil (sense 2)): from Latin instillare, from in- ‘into’ + stillare ‘to drop’ (from stilla ‘a drop’).

definitions.definition: gradually but firmly establish (an idea or attitude) in a person's mind.
definitions.example: the standards her parents had instilled into her

definitions.definition: put (a substance) into something in the form of liquid drops.
definitions.example: she was told how to instil eye drops

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin lucrativus, from lucrat- ‘gained’, from the verb lucrari, from lucrum (see lucre).

definitions.definition: producing a great deal of profit.
definitions.example: a lucrative career as a stand-up comedian

words.origin: early 16th century: from Latin praecipitat- ‘thrown headlong’, from the verb praecipitare, from praeceps, praecip(it)- ‘headlong’, from prae ‘before’ + caput ‘head’. The original sense of the verb was ‘hurl down, send violently’; hence ‘cause to move rapidly’, which gave rise to sense 1 (early 17th century).

definitions.definition: cause (an event or situation, typically one that is undesirable) to happen suddenly, unexpectedly, or prematurely.
definitions.example: the incident precipitated a political crisis

definitions.definition: cause (a substance) to be deposited in solid form from a solution.
definitions.example: cell proteins were then precipitated and washed in 10% trichloroacetic acid

definitions.definition: done, made, or acting suddenly or without careful consideration.
definitions.example: I must apologize for my staff—their actions were precipitate

definitions.definition: a substance precipitated from a solution.

words.origin: late 16th century: from Latin proponent- ‘putting forth’, from the verb proponere (see propound).

definitions.definition: a person who advocates a theory, proposal, or course of action.
definitions.example: a strong proponent of the free market and liberal trade policies

definitions.definition: an increase or revival after a period of little activity, popularity, or occurrence.
definitions.example: a resurgence of interest in religion

definitions.definition: imbue (something) with new life and vitality.
definitions.example: a package of spending cuts to revitalize the economy
synonyms: give a shot in the arm to

words.origin: early 19th century: from water + shed in the sense ‘ridge of high ground’ (related to shed2), suggested by German Wasserscheide .

definitions.definition: an area or ridge of land that separates waters flowing to different rivers, basins, or seas.
an event or period marking a turning point in a situation.
definitions.example: these works were a watershed in the history of music

words.origin: early 17th century: via Latin from Greek, neuter of automatos ‘acting of itself’, from autos ‘self’.

definitions.definition: a moving mechanical device made in imitation of a human being.
definitions.example: a collection of 19th century French automata: acrobats, clowns, and musicians

words.origin: Old English belēogan  ‘deceive by lying’, from be- ‘about’ + lēogan ‘to lie’. Current senses date from the 17th century.

definitions.definition: (of an appearance) fail to give a true impression of (something).
definitions.example: his lively, alert manner belied his years

definitions.definition: fail to fulfil or justify (a claim or expectation).
definitions.example: the quality of the music seems to belie the criticism

words.origin: late Middle English: from Old French cupidite or Latin cupiditas, from cupidus ‘desirous’, from cupere ‘to desire’. Compare with covet.

definitions.definition: greed for money or possessions.
definitions.example: new wealth, however tainted by cupidity and egoism, tends to be favourable for the arts

words.origin: early 19th century (in sense ‘the breaking up of ice in a river’): from French débâcle, from débâcler ‘unleash’, from dé- ‘un-’ + bâcler ‘to bar’ (from Latin baculum ‘staff’).

definitions.definition: a sudden and ignominious failure; a fiasco.
definitions.example: the only man to reach double figures in the second-innings debacle

words.origin: mid 17th century: from Greek dēmagōgos, from dēmos ‘the people’ + agōgos ‘leading’ (from agein ‘to lead’).

definitions.definition: a political leader who seeks support by appealing to the desires and prejudices of ordinary people rather than by using rational argument.
definitions.example: a gifted demagogue with particular skill in manipulating the press

definitions.definition: rhetorically exploit (an issue) for political purposes in a way calculated to appeal to the desires and prejudices of ordinary people.
definitions.example: he seems more interested in demagoguing the issue in media interviews than in dialogue

words.origin: mid 16th century: from Latin deterrere, from de- ‘away from’ + terrere ‘frighten’.

definitions.definition: discourage (someone) from doing something by instilling doubt or fear of the consequences.
definitions.example: only a health problem would deter him from seeking re-election

words.origin: mid 16th century: from dis- (expressing reversal) + credit, on the pattern of Italian ( di)scredito (noun), ( di)screditare (verb), and French discrédit (noun), discréditer (verb).

definitions.definition: harm the good reputation of.
definitions.example: his remarks were taken out of context in an effort to discredit him

definitions.definition: loss or lack of reputation or respect.
definitions.example: his actions were such that they brought discredit on his profession

words.origin: late 19th century: from the name of Draco (see Draco2) + -ian.

definitions.definition: (of laws or their application) excessively harsh and severe.
definitions.example: the Nazis destroyed the independence of the press by a series of draconian laws

definitions.definition: deceitful.
definitions.example: a duplicitous philanderer

definitions.definition: (of a charge or plea) containing more than one allegation.

words.origin: mid 17th century: from Latin exacerbat- ‘made harsh’, from the verb exacerbare, from ex- (expressing inducement of a state) + acerbus ‘harsh, bitter’.

definitions.definition: make (a problem, bad situation, or negative feeling) worse.
definitions.example: the exorbitant cost of land in urban areas only exacerbated the problem

words.origin: late Middle English: from French ignominieux, or Latin ignominiosus, from ignominia (see ignominy).

definitions.definition: deserving or causing public disgrace or shame.
definitions.example: no other party risked ignominious defeat

words.origin: mid 16th century: from Latin insidiosus ‘cunning’, from insidiae ‘an ambush or trick’, from insidere ‘lie in wait for’, from in- ‘on’ + sedere ‘sit’.

definitions.definition: proceeding in a gradual, subtle way, but with very harmful effects.
definitions.example: sexual harassment is a serious and insidious problem

definitions.definition: short-sighted.
definitions.example: most myopic children can be fitted with glasses to correct their vision

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin perniciosus ‘destructive’, from pernicies ‘ruin’, based on nex, nec- ‘death’.

definitions.definition: having a harmful effect, especially in a gradual or subtle way.
definitions.example: the pernicious influences of the mass media

words.origin: late 15th century: from Spanish renegado, from medieval Latin renegatus ‘renounced’, past participle (used as a noun) of renegare, from re- (expressing intensive force) + Latin negare ‘deny’.

definitions.definition: a person who deserts and betrays an organization, country, or set of principles.
definitions.example: an agent who later turns out to be a renegade

definitions.definition: having treacherously changed allegiance.
definitions.example: a renegade bodyguard

definitions.definition: become a renegade.
definitions.example: Johnson had renegaded from the Confederacy

words.origin: late 16th century (in the sense ‘mark with a brand’): from French stigmatiser or medieval Latin stigmatizare, from Greek stigmatizein, from stigma (see stigma).

definitions.definition: describe or regard as worthy of disgrace or great disapproval.
definitions.example: the institution was stigmatized as a last resort for the destitute

definitions.definition: mark with stigmata.
definitions.example: Francis, stigmatized in fashion as his Lord

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin superfluus, from super- ‘over’ + fluere ‘to flow’.

definitions.definition: unnecessary, especially through being more than enough.
definitions.example: the purchaser should avoid asking for superfluous information

words.origin: mid 17th century (in the sense ‘available for purchase’, referring to merchandise or a favour): from Latin venalis, from venum ‘thing for sale’.

definitions.definition: showing or motivated by susceptibility to bribery; corrupt.
definitions.example: local customs officers are notoriously venal

words.origin: late Middle English (originally describing a poisoned wound): from Latin virulentus, from virus ‘poison’ (see virus).

definitions.definition: (of a disease or poison) extremely severe or harmful in its effects.
definitions.example: a virulent strain of influenza

definitions.definition: bitterly hostile.
definitions.example: his involvement with the temperance movement led to his virulent attack on the drink trade

words.origin: late Middle English (as an epithet of the apostle Simon): via ecclesiastical Latin from Greek zēlōtēs, from zēloun ‘be zealous’, from zēlos (see zeal).

definitions.definition: a person who is fanatical and uncompromising in pursuit of their religious, political, or other ideals.
a member of an ancient Jewish sect that aimed at a world Jewish theocracy and resisted the Romans until AD 70.

words.origin: early 17th century: from Greek autonomia, from autonomos ‘having its own laws’, from autos ‘self’ + nomos ‘law’.

definitions.definition: the right or condition of self-government.
definitions.example: between the First and Second World Wars, Canada gained greater autonomy from Britain

definitions.definition: (in Kantian moral philosophy) the capacity of an agent to act in accordance with objective morality rather than under the influence of desires.

words.origin: late 16th century: of unknown origin, but first recorded in a work by Thomas Nashe, as a term of abuse for a crank or pedant, later coming to denote a whim or fancy, also a pun. Current senses date from the late 17th century.

definitions.definition: a confusing and difficult problem or question.
definitions.example: one of the most difficult conundrums for the experts

words.origin: late 16th century: via modern Latin from Greek dikhotomia, from dikho- ‘in two, apart’ + -tomia (see -tomy).

definitions.definition: a division or contrast between two things that are or are represented as being opposed or entirely different.
definitions.example: a rigid dichotomy between science and mysticism

definitions.definition: repeated branching into two equal parts.

words.origin: mid 16th century: from French disparité, from late Latin disparitas, based on Latin paritas ‘parity’.

definitions.definition: a great difference.
definitions.example: economic disparities between different regions of the country

words.origin: mid 16th century (as a noun denoting something that divides or separates): from late Latin divisivus, from Latin dividere (see divide).

definitions.definition: tending to cause disagreement or hostility between people.
definitions.example: the highly divisive issue of abortion

words.origin: late 19th century: from French égalitaire, from égal ‘equal’, from Latin aequalis (see equal).

definitions.definition: believing in or based on the principle that all people are equal and deserve equal rights and opportunities.
definitions.example: a fairer, more egalitarian society

definitions.definition: a person who advocates or supports the principle of equality for all people.
definitions.example: he was a social and political egalitarian

words.origin: late 16th century: from Latin aberratio(n- ), from aberrare ‘to stray’ (see aberrant).

definitions.definition: a departure from what is normal, usual, or expected, typically an unwelcome one.
definitions.example: they described the outbreak of violence in the area as an aberration

words.origin: early 18th century: from French, or from modern Latin armistitium, from arma ‘arms’ (see arm2) + -stitium ‘stoppage’.

definitions.definition: an agreement made by opposing sides in a war to stop fighting for a certain time; a truce.

words.origin: Old English clēofan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch klieven and German klieben .

definitions.definition: split or sever (something), especially along a natural line or grain.
definitions.example: the large axe his father used to cleave wood for the fire

words.origin: late 16th century: from French débaucher (verb) ‘turn away from one's duty’, from Old French desbaucher, of uncertain ultimate origin.

definitions.definition: destroy or debase the moral purity of; corrupt.
definitions.example: he has debauched the morals of the people and endeavoured to corrupt parliament

definitions.definition: a bout of excessive indulgence in sex, alcohol, or drugs.
definitions.example: Patrick looked utterly untouched by the previous night's debauch

words.origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘deserted, abandoned, empty’): from Latin destitutus, past participle of destituere ‘forsake’, from de- ‘away from’ + statuere ‘to place’.

definitions.definition: extremely poor and lacking the means to provide for oneself.
definitions.example: the charity cares for destitute children
synonyms: without a penny to one's name
as poor as a church mouse

words.origin: late 17th century (in the sense ‘upset the progress of’): from obsolete French desconcerter, from des- (expressing reversal) + concerter ‘bring together’.

definitions.definition: disturb the composure of; unsettle.
definitions.example: the abrupt change of subject disconcerted her
synonyms: cause to be at a stand

words.origin: French, from Latin spiritus ‘spirit’.

definitions.definition: the quality of being lively, vivacious, or witty.

words.origin: French, literally ‘spirit of the body’.

definitions.definition: a feeling of pride and mutual loyalty shared by the members of a group.
definitions.example: they developed some esprit de corps through athletics competitions

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin fastidiosus, from fastidium ‘loathing’. The word originally meant ‘disagreeable’, later ‘disgusted’. Current senses date from the 17th century.

definitions.definition: very attentive to and concerned about accuracy and detail.
definitions.example: she dressed with fastidious care

words.origin: mid 16th century: from Latin impingere ‘drive something in or at’, from in- ‘into’ + pangere ‘fix, drive’. The word originally meant ‘thrust at forcibly’, then ‘come into forcible contact’; hence ‘encroach’ (mid 18th century).

definitions.definition: have an effect, especially a negative one.
definitions.example: several factors impinge on market efficiency

words.origin: late 15th century: from ecclesiastical Latin insensatus, from in- ‘not’ + sensatus ‘having senses’ (see sensate).

definitions.definition: lacking physical sensation.
definitions.example: a patient who was permanently unconscious and insensate

definitions.definition: completely lacking sense or reason.
definitions.example: insensate jabbering

words.origin: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘Laconian’): via Latin from Greek Lakōnikos, from Lakōn ‘Laconia, Sparta’, the Spartans being known for their terse speech.

definitions.definition: (of a person, speech, or style of writing) using very few words.
definitions.example: his laconic reply suggested a lack of interest in the topic

words.origin: late 16th century: from Latin pallidus ‘pale’ (related to pallere ‘be pale’).

definitions.definition: (of a person's face) pale, typically because of poor health.
definitions.example: his face, with its wrinkled, pallid complexion

definitions.definition: lacking vigour or intensity; insipid.
definitions.example: a pallid ray of winter sun

words.origin: mid 17th century: from obsolete French précipiteux, from Latin praeceps, praecip(it)- ‘steep, headlong’ (see precipitate).

definitions.definition: dangerously high or steep.
definitions.example: the track skirted a precipitous drop

definitions.definition: (of an action) done suddenly and without careful consideration.
definitions.example: precipitous intervention

words.origin: late Middle English: from late Latin renuntiatio(n- ), from Latin renuntiare ‘protest against’ (see renounce).

definitions.definition: the formal rejection of something, typically a belief, claim, or course of action.
definitions.example: the life of the Spirit required renunciation of marriage

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin, from stupere ‘be amazed or stunned’.

definitions.definition: a state of near-unconsciousness or insensibility.
definitions.example: a drunken stupor

words.origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘obtained by suppression of the truth’): from Latin surreptitius (from the verb surripere, from sub- ‘secretly’ + rapere ‘seize’) + -ous.

definitions.definition: kept secret, especially because it would not be approved of.
definitions.example: low wages were supplemented by surreptitious payments from tradesmen

words.origin: early 17th century: from Latin tremulus (from tremere ‘tremble’) + -ous.

definitions.definition: shaking or quivering slightly.
definitions.example: Barbara's voice was tremulous

definitions.definition: not having or showing foresight; spendthrift or thoughtless.
definitions.example: improvident and undisciplined behaviour

words.origin: Middle English: from Old French herbergere, from herbergier ‘provide lodging for’, from herberge ‘lodging’, from Old Saxon heriberga ‘shelter for an army, lodging’ (from heri ‘army’ + a Germanic base meaning ‘fortified place’), related to harbour. The term originally denoted a person who provided lodging, later one who went ahead to find lodgings for an army or for a nobleman and his retinue, hence, a herald (mid 16th century).

definitions.definition: a person or thing that announces or signals the approach of another.
definitions.example: witch hazels are the harbingers of spring

definitions.definition: without intention; accidentally.
definitions.example: his name had been inadvertently omitted from the list

words.origin: late 16th century (as a noun denoting a beginner): from Latin incipient- ‘undertaking, beginning’, from the verb incipere, from in- ‘into, towards’ + capere ‘take’.

definitions.definition: beginning to happen or develop.
definitions.example: he could feel incipient anger building up

words.origin: early 19th century (in the sense ‘relating to a commune, especially the Paris Commune’): from French, from late Latin communalis, from communis (see common).

definitions.definition: shared by all members of a community; for common use.
definitions.example: a communal bathroom and kitchen

definitions.definition: (of conflict) between different communities, especially those having different religions or ethnic origins.
definitions.example: violent communal riots

words.origin: Middle English (originally in the sense ‘make or become united or reconciled’, rare before the 16th century): from at one in early use; later by back-formation from atonement.

definitions.definition: make amends or reparation.
definitions.example: a human sacrifice to atone for the sin

words.origin: late 16th century (originally Scots in the sense ‘relating to the occult, malicious’): from un-1 ‘not’ + canny.

definitions.definition: strange or mysterious, especially in an unsettling way.
definitions.example: an uncanny feeling that she was being watched

words.origin: early 17th century: from Latin emissarius ‘scout, spy’, from emittere ‘send out’ (see emit).

definitions.definition: a person sent as a diplomatic representative on a special mission.

words.origin: early 17th century: from French capricieux, from Italian (see capriccioso).

definitions.definition: given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behaviour.
definitions.example: it's terrible to feel our livelihood hinges on a capricious boss

words.origin: mid 16th century: from Latin imperiosus, from imperium ‘command, authority, empire’; related to imperare ‘to command’. Compare with imperial.

definitions.definition: arrogant and domineering.
definitions.example: his imperious demands

words.origin: Middle English (originally in the sense ‘force back, repress’): from Anglo-Norman French and Old Northern French rebuker, from re- ‘back, down’ + bukier ‘to beat’ (originally ‘cut down wood’, from Old French busche ‘log’).

definitions.definition: express sharp disapproval or criticism of (someone) because of their behaviour or actions.
definitions.example: she had rebuked him for drinking too much

definitions.definition: an expression of sharp disapproval or criticism.
definitions.example: he hadn't meant it as a rebuke, but Neil flinched

words.origin: mid 17th century: from Greek ostrakizein, from ostrakon ‘shell or potsherd’ (on which names were written in voting to banish unpopular citizens).

definitions.definition: exclude from a society or group.
definitions.example: she was declared a witch and ostracized by the villagers

definitions.definition: (in ancient Greece) banish (an unpopular or overly powerful citizen) from a city for five or ten years by popular vote.
definitions.example: Themistocles was indeed out of favour at Athens by the end of the 470s, when he was ostracized

words.origin: late 17th century: from de- (expressing reversal) + a shortened form of consecrate.

definitions.definition: treat (a sacred place or thing) with violent disrespect.
definitions.example: more than 300 graves were desecrated

words.origin: mid 17th century: from Latin resilient- ‘leaping back’, from the verb resilire (see resile).

definitions.definition: (of a person or animal) able to withstand or recover quickly from difficult conditions.
definitions.example: babies are generally far more resilient than new parents realize

definitions.definition: (of a substance or object) able to recoil or spring back into shape after bending, stretching, or being compressed.
definitions.example: a shoe with resilient cushioning

words.origin: Middle English (as an adjective in the sense ‘disbelieving’): from Old French mescreant, present participle of mescreire ‘disbelieve’, from mes- ‘mis-’ + creire ‘believe’ (from Latin credere ).

definitions.definition: a person who has done something wrong or unlawful.
definitions.example: the police are straining every nerve to bring the miscreants to justice

definitions.definition: (of a person) behaving badly or unlawfully.
definitions.example: her miscreant husband

words.origin: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin enormitas, from enormis, from e- (variant of ex- ) ‘out of’ + norma ‘pattern, standard’. The word originally meant ‘deviation from legal or moral rectitude’ and ‘transgression’. Current senses have been influenced by enormous.

definitions.definition: the great or extreme scale, seriousness, or extent of something perceived as bad or morally wrong.
definitions.example: a thorough search disclosed the full enormity of the crime

definitions.definition: a grave crime or sin.
definitions.example: the enormities of war

words.origin: Middle English: from Old French apaisier, from a- (from Latin ad ‘to, at’) + pais ‘peace’.

definitions.definition: pacify or placate (someone) by acceding to their demands.
definitions.example: amendments have been added to appease local pressure groups

definitions.definition: assuage or satisfy (a demand or a feeling).
definitions.example: we give to charity because it appeases our guilt

definitions.definition: the action of admitting someone into a secret or obscure society or group, typically with a ritual.
definitions.example: rituals of initiation

definitions.definition: the action of beginning something.
definitions.example: the initiation of criminal proceedings

words.origin: late Middle English: from Old French adherent, from Latin adhaerent- ‘sticking to’, from the verb adhaerere (see adhere).

definitions.definition: someone who supports a particular party, person, or set of ideas.
definitions.example: he was a strong adherent of monetarism

definitions.definition: sticking fast to an object or surface.
definitions.example: the eggs have thick sticky shells to which debris is often adherent

words.origin: early 16th century: from a medieval Latin derivative of Latin zelus ‘zeal, jealousy’.

definitions.definition: having or showing zeal.
definitions.example: the council was extremely zealous in the application of the regulations

words.origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘rejected’): from Latin abjectus, past participle of abicere ‘reject’, from ab- ‘away’ + jacere ‘to throw’.

definitions.definition: (of something bad) experienced or present to the maximum degree.
definitions.example: his letter plunged her into abject misery

definitions.definition: (of a person or their behaviour) completely without pride or dignity; self-abasing.
definitions.example: an abject apology

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin abjurare, from ab- ‘away’ + jurare ‘swear’.

definitions.definition: solemnly renounce (a belief, cause, or claim).
definitions.example: MPs were urged to abjure their Jacobite allegiance

words.origin: Middle English: from Latin abnegatio(n- ), from the verb abnegare (see abnegate).

definitions.definition: the action of renouncing or rejecting something.
definitions.example: abnegation of political power

words.origin: early 16th century: from Latin abrogat- ‘repealed’, from the verb abrogare, from ab- ‘away, from’ + rogare ‘propose a law’.

definitions.definition: repeal or do away with (a law, right, or formal agreement).
definitions.example: a proposal to abrogate temporarily the right to strike

definitions.definition: evade (a responsibility or duty).
definitions.example: we believe the board is abrogating its responsibilities to its shareholders

words.origin: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘hide, conceal oneself’): from Latin abscondere ‘hide’, from ab- ‘away, from’ + condere ‘stow’.

definitions.definition: leave hurriedly and secretly, typically to escape from custody or avoid arrest.
definitions.example: the barman absconded with a week's takings
synonyms: show a clean pair of heels

words.origin: late 16th century: from Latin abstrusus ‘put away, hidden’, from abstrudere ‘conceal’, from ab- ‘from’ + trudere ‘to push’.

definitions.definition: difficult to understand; obscure.
definitions.example: an abstruse philosophical inquiry

words.origin: late Middle English (in the general sense ‘come forward, approach’): from Latin accedere, from ad- ‘to’ + cedere ‘give way, yield’.

definitions.definition: agree to a demand, request, or treaty.
definitions.example: the authorities did not accede to the strikers' demands

definitions.definition: assume an office or position.
definitions.example: Elizabeth I acceded to the throne in 1558

words.origin: late 16th century (originally in the sense ‘lie or go alongside’): from French accoster, from Italian accostare, from Latin ad- ‘to’ + costa ‘rib, side’.

definitions.definition: approach and address (someone) boldly or aggressively.
definitions.example: reporters accosted him in the street

words.origin: early 17th century: from Latin accretio(n- ), from accrescere ‘become larger’ (see accrete).

definitions.definition: growth or increase by the gradual accumulation of additional layers or matter.
definitions.example: the accretion of sediments in coastal mangroves

words.origin: late 16th century: from Latin, ‘sharpness, point’, from acuere ‘sharpen’ (see acute).

definitions.definition: the ability to make good judgements and take quick decisions.
definitions.example: she hides a shrewd business acumen

words.origin: Old English (as a noun), from Old French adamaunt-, via Latin from Greek adamas, adamant-, ‘untameable, invincible’ (later used to denote the hardest metal or stone, hence diamond), from a- ‘not’ + daman ‘to tame’. The phrase to be adamant dates from the 1930s, although adjectival use had been implied in such collocations as ‘an adamant heart’ since the 16th century.

definitions.definition: refusing to be persuaded or to change one's mind.
definitions.example: he is adamant that he is not going to resign

definitions.definition: a legendary rock or mineral to which many properties were attributed, formerly associated with diamond or lodestone.

words.origin: Middle English amonest  ‘urge, exhort’, from Old French amonester, based on Latin admonere ‘urge by warning’. Later, the final -t of amonest was taken to indicate the past tense, and the present tense changed on the pattern of verbs such as abolish ; the prefix became ad- in the 16th century by association with the Latin form.

definitions.definition: warn or reprimand someone firmly.
definitions.example: she admonished me for appearing at breakfast unshaven
synonyms: give a piece of one's mind to

words.origin: late 16th century: from Latin adumbrat- ‘shaded’, from the verb adumbrare, from ad- ‘to’ (as an intensifier) + umbrare ‘cast a shadow’ (from umbra ‘shade’).

definitions.definition: represent in outline.
definitions.example: Hobhouse had already adumbrated the idea of a welfare state

definitions.definition: foreshadow (a future event).
definitions.example: tenors solemnly adumbrate the fate of the convicted sinner

definitions.definition: overshadow.
definitions.example: her happy reminiscences were adumbrated by consciousness of something else

words.origin: late Middle English: from Old French advers, from Latin adversus ‘against, opposite’, past participle of advertere, from ad- ‘to’ + vertere ‘to turn’. Compare with averse.

definitions.definition: preventing success or development; harmful; unfavourable.
definitions.example: taxes are having an adverse effect on production

words.origin: Middle English: from Old French avocat, from Latin advocatus, past participle (used as a noun) of advocare ‘call (to one's aid)’, from ad- ‘to’ + vocare ‘to call’.

definitions.definition: a person who publicly supports or recommends a particular cause or policy.
definitions.example: he was an untiring advocate of economic reform

definitions.definition: a person who puts a case on someone else's behalf.
definitions.example: care managers can become advocates for their clients

definitions.definition: publicly recommend or support.
definitions.example: voters supported candidates who advocated an Assembly

words.origin: late Middle English (in affluent (sense 2 of the adjective)): via Old French from Latin affluent- ‘flowing towards, flowing freely’, from the verb affluere, from ad- ‘to’ + fluere ‘to flow’.

definitions.definition: (especially of a group or area) having a great deal of money; wealthy.
definitions.example: the affluent societies of the western world

definitions.definition: (of water) flowing freely or in great quantity.
a tributary stream.

words.origin: mid 17th century (in the general sense ‘increase, magnify’): from French agrandiss-, lengthened stem of agrandir, probably from Italian aggrandire, from Latin grandis ‘large’. The ending was changed by association with verbs ending in -ize.

definitions.definition: increase the power, status, or wealth of.
definitions.example: an action intended to aggrandize the Frankish dynasty

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin alacritas, from alacer ‘brisk’.

definitions.definition: brisk and cheerful readiness.
definitions.example: she accepted the invitation with alacrity

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin, ‘at another time, otherwise’.

definitions.definition: used to indicate that a named person is also known or more familiar under another specified name.
definitions.example: Eric Blair, alias George Orwell

definitions.definition: a false or assumed identity.
definitions.example: a spy operating under the alias Barsad

definitions.definition: each of a set of signal frequencies which, when sampled at a given uniform rate, would give the same set of sampled values, and thus might be incorrectly substituted for one another when reconstructing the original signal.
misidentify (a signal frequency), introducing distortion or error.
definitions.example: fringes at higher spatial frequency are aliased by the sensor

words.origin: early 20th century: from ambivalence (from German Ambivalenz ), on the pattern of equivalent .

definitions.definition: having mixed feelings or contradictory ideas about something or someone.
definitions.example: some loved her, some hated her, few were ambivalent about her
synonyms: on the horns of a dilemma

words.origin: late 16th century (in the sense ‘liable to answer to a law or tribunal’): an Anglo-Norman French legal term, from Old French amener ‘bring to’ from a- (from Latin ad ) ‘to’ + mener ‘bring’ (from late Latin minare ‘drive animals’, from Latin minari ‘threaten’).

definitions.definition: open and responsive to suggestion; easily persuaded or controlled.
definitions.example: parents who have amenable children

words.origin: mid 18th century: from modern Latin amorphus, from Greek amorphos ‘shapeless’ (from a- ‘without’ + morphē ‘form’) + -ous.

definitions.definition: without a clearly defined shape or form.
definitions.example: an amorphous, characterless conurbation

definitions.definition: belonging to a period other than that being portrayed.
definitions.example: 'Titus' benefits from the effective use of anachronistic elements like cars and loudspeakers

words.origin: early 16th century: from ecclesiastical Latin, ‘excommunicated person, excommunication’, from Greek anathema ‘thing dedicated’, (later) ‘thing devoted to evil, accursed thing’, from anatithenai ‘to set up’.

definitions.definition: something or someone that one vehemently dislikes.
definitions.example: racial hatred was anathema to her

definitions.definition: a formal curse by a pope or a council of the Church, excommunicating a person or denouncing a doctrine.
definitions.example: the Pope laid special emphasis on the second of these anathemas

words.origin: late Middle English: from Old French annexer, from Latin annectere ‘connect’, from ad- ‘to’ + nectere ‘tie, fasten’.

definitions.definition: add as an extra or subordinate part, especially to a document.
definitions.example: the first ten amendments were annexed to the Constitution in 1791

definitions.definition: add (territory) to one's own territory by appropriation.
definitions.example: the left bank of the Rhine was annexed by France in 1797

definitions.definition: a building joined to or associated with a main building, providing additional space or accommodation.
definitions.example: the school's one-storey wooden annex

definitions.definition: an addition to a document.
definitions.example: an annex to the report

words.origin: mid 17th century: from ante- + Latin diluvium ‘deluge’ + -an.

definitions.definition: of or belonging to the time before the biblical Flood.
definitions.example: gigantic bones of antediluvian animals

definitions.definition: preventing the growth of disease-causing microorganisms.
definitions.example: garlic has powerful antiseptic properties

definitions.definition: scrupulously clean or pure, especially so as to be bland or characterless.
definitions.example: their squeaky-clean home epitomizes this antiseptic respectability

definitions.definition: an antiseptic compound or preparation.
definitions.example: the inappropriate use of antiseptics

words.origin: mid 18th century: from apathy, on the pattern of pathetic .

definitions.definition: showing or feeling no interest, enthusiasm, or concern.
definitions.example: an apathetic electorate

words.origin: late Middle English (originally denoting the substitution of one grammatical case for another): from late Latin, from Greek antitithenai ‘set against’, from anti ‘against’ + tithenai ‘to place’. The earliest current sense, denoting a rhetorical or literary device, dates from the early 16th century.

definitions.definition: a person or thing that is the direct opposite of someone or something else.
definitions.example: love is the antithesis of selfishness
synonyms: the other side of the coin

definitions.definition: (in Hegelian philosophy) the negation of the thesis as the second stage in the process of dialectical reasoning.
(of a story or statement) of doubtful authenticity, although widely circulated as being true.
definitions.example: his alleged description of opera as ‘fat gits singing’ is probably apocryphal

words.origin: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin approbatio(n- ), from the verb approbare (see approbate).

definitions.definition: approval or praise.
definitions.example: a term of approbation

words.origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘dependent on one's will or pleasure, discretionary’): from Latin arbitrarius, from arbiter ‘judge, supreme ruler’, perhaps influenced by French arbitraire .

definitions.definition: based on random choice or personal whim, rather than any reason or system.
definitions.example: an arbitrary decision

definitions.definition: (of power or a ruling body) unrestrained and autocratic in the use of authority.
definitions.example: a country under arbitrary government

definitions.definition: (of a constant or other quantity) of unspecified value.

words.origin: mid 17th century: from Latin arboreus, from arbor ‘tree’, + -al.

definitions.definition: living in trees.
definitions.example: arboreal rodents

words.origin: mid 16th century: from Latin arcanus, from arcere ‘to shut up’, from arca ‘chest’.

definitions.definition: understood by few; mysterious or secret.
definitions.example: arcane procedures for electing people

definitions.definition: very typical of a certain kind of person or thing.
definitions.example: the archetypal country doctor

definitions.definition: relating to or denoting Jungian archetypes.
recurrent as a symbol or motif in literature, art, or mythology.
definitions.example: an archetypal journey representing the quest for identity

words.origin: mid 16th century: from Latin arrogat- ‘claimed for oneself’, from the verb arrogare, from ad- ‘to’ + rogare ‘ask’.

definitions.definition: take or claim (something) without justification.
definitions.example: they arrogate to themselves the ability to divine the nation's true interests

words.origin: mid 17th century: from medieval Latin asceticus or Greek askētikos, from askētēs ‘monk’, from askein ‘to exercise’.

definitions.definition: characterized by severe self-discipline and abstention from all forms of indulgence, typically for religious reasons.
definitions.example: an ascetic life of prayer, fasting, and manual labour

definitions.definition: a person who follows an ascetic life.

words.origin: late Middle English (denoting the sprinkling of water, especially at baptism): from Latin aspersio(n- ), from aspergere (see asperse).

definitions.definition: an attack on the reputation or integrity of someone or something.
definitions.example: I don't think anyone is casting aspersions on you

words.origin: mid 16th century: from Latin assiduus, from assidere ‘be engaged in doing’ (see assess), + -ous.

definitions.definition: showing great care and perseverance.
definitions.example: she was assiduous in pointing out every feature

words.origin: late 16th century: from French atrophier (verb), atrophie (noun), from late Latin atrophia, from Greek, ‘lack of food’, from atrophos ‘poorly nourished’, from a- ‘without’ + trophē ‘food’.

definitions.definition: (of body tissue or an organ) waste away, especially as a result of the degeneration of cells, or become vestigial during evolution.
definitions.example: the calf muscles will atrophy

definitions.definition: gradually decline in effectiveness or vigour due to underuse or neglect.
definitions.example: the imagination can atrophy from lack of use

definitions.definition: the process of atrophying or state of having atrophied.
definitions.example: gastric atrophy

words.origin: Old English bana  ‘thing causing death, poison’, of Germanic origin.

definitions.definition: a cause of great distress or annoyance.
definitions.example: the telephone was the bane of my life

definitions.definition: something, especially poison, which causes death.

words.origin: late 15th century: from obsolete bash  ‘make or become abashed’ (from abash) + -ful.

definitions.definition: reluctant to draw attention to oneself; shy.
definitions.example: everything you need to know but have been too bashful to ask

words.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘deceive, deprive of by fraud’): from be- ‘thoroughly’ + obsolete guile ‘to deceive’ (see guile).

definitions.definition: charm or enchant (someone), often in a deceptive way.
definitions.example: he beguiled the voters with his good looks

definitions.definition: help (time) pass pleasantly.
definitions.example: to beguile some of the time they went to the cinema

words.origin: late 16th century: archaic past participle of bereave.

definitions.definition: deprived of or lacking (something).
definitions.example: her room was stark and bereft of colour

definitions.definition: (of a person) sad and lonely, especially through someone's death or departure.
definitions.example: his death in 1990 left her bereft

definitions.definition: a flattering or pleasing statement or action used as a means of gently persuading someone to do something.
definitions.example: the blandishments of the travel brochure

words.origin: mid 17th century (originally used in cribbage meaning ‘spoil one's opponent's score’): perhaps a variant of balk.

definitions.definition: obtain or withhold money from (someone) unfairly or by deceit; cheat or defraud.
definitions.example: an apparently benevolent elderly gentleman bilked me of twenty dollars

definitions.definition: evade; elude.
high-sounding but with little meaning; inflated.
definitions.example: bombastic rhetoric

words.origin: mid 17th century: from French cajoler .

definitions.definition: persuade (someone) to do something by sustained coaxing or flattery.
definitions.example: he hoped to cajole her into selling the house

words.origin: late Middle English (in the Latin sense): from Latin callosus ‘hard-skinned’.

definitions.definition: showing or having an insensitive and cruel disregard for others.
definitions.example: his callous comments about the murder made me shiver

definitions.definition: variant spelling of callus.

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin calumnia .

definitions.definition: the making of false and defamatory statements about someone in order to damage their reputation; slander.
definitions.example: a bitter struggle marked by calumny and litigation

definitions.definition: slander (someone).

words.origin: mid 19th century: from French, from camarade ‘comrade’.

definitions.definition: mutual trust and friendship among people who spend a lot of time together.
definitions.example: the enforced camaraderie of office life

words.origin: late Middle English (in the Latin sense): from Latin candor ‘whiteness’. The current sense dates from the mid 18th century; the development of the senses paralleled that of candid.

definitions.definition: the quality of being open and honest; frankness.
definitions.example: a man of refreshing candour

words.origin: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘parley, draw up terms’): from French capituler, from medieval Latin capitulare ‘draw up under headings’, from Latin capitulum, diminutive of caput ‘head’.

definitions.definition: cease to resist an opponent or an unwelcome demand; yield.
definitions.example: the patriots had to capitulate to the enemy forces

words.origin: mid 16th century: originally as an adverb meaning ‘right out, completely’ in the phrase drink carouse, from German gar aus trinken ; hence ‘drink heavily, have a drinking bout’.

definitions.definition: drink alcohol and enjoy oneself with others in a noisy, lively way.
definitions.example: they danced and caroused until the drink ran out

definitions.definition: a noisy, lively drinking party.
definitions.example: corporate carouses

words.origin: mid 18th century: perhaps from Algonquian cau'-cau'-as'u ‘adviser’.

definitions.definition: (in some US states) a meeting at which local members of a political party register their preference among candidates running for office or select delegates to attend a convention.
definitions.example: Hawaii holds its nominating caucuses next Tuesday

definitions.definition: a conference of members of a legislative body who belong to a particular party or faction.
a group within an organization or political party which meets independently to discuss strategy or tactics.
definitions.example: up to fifty caucuses met daily on conference grounds to discuss lobbying strategies

definitions.definition: hold or form a legislative caucus.
definitions.example: Republicans briefly caucused

words.origin: late 18th century (originally US): perhaps an alteration of curvet.

definitions.definition: jump or dance around excitedly.
definitions.example: the players cavorted about the pitch

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin circumlocutio(n- ) (translating Greek periphrasis ), from circum ‘around’ + locutio(n- ) from loqui ‘speak’.

definitions.definition: the use of many words where fewer would do, especially in a deliberate attempt to be vague or evasive.
definitions.example: his admission came after years of circumlocution

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin circumscribere, from circum ‘around’ + scribere ‘write’.

definitions.definition: restrict (something) within limits.
definitions.example: the minister's powers are circumscribed both by tradition and the organization of local government

definitions.definition: draw (a figure) round another, touching it at points but not cutting it.
definitions.example: if a hexagon is circumscribed about a circle the lines joining opposite vertices meet in one point

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin circumvent- ‘skirted around’, from the verb circumvenire, from circum ‘around’ + venire ‘come’.

definitions.definition: find a way around (an obstacle).
definitions.example: if you come to an obstruction in a road you can seek to circumvent it

words.origin: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin clamor, from clamare ‘cry out’.

definitions.definition: a loud and confused noise, especially that of people shouting.
definitions.example: the questions rose to a clamour

definitions.definition: (of a group of people) shout loudly and insistently.
definitions.example: the surging crowds clamoured for attention

words.origin: Middle English: of unknown origin.

definitions.definition: a person whose job is mending shoes.
an iced drink made with wine or sherry, sugar, and lemon.
definitions.example: sherry cobbler

definitions.definition: a dessert consisting of fruit baked in a deep dish with a thick, cake-like crust on top.
definitions.example: apricot cobbler

definitions.definition: a man's testicles.
definitions.example: I've been kicked in the cobblers a few times

definitions.definition: the last sheep to be shorn.

words.origin: mid 17th century: from Latin cogent- ‘compelling’, from the verb cogere, from co- ‘together’ + agere ‘drive’.

definitions.definition: (of an argument or case) clear, logical, and convincing.
definitions.example: they put forward cogent arguments for British membership

words.origin: early 19th century: probably directly from cognizance.

definitions.definition: having knowledge or awareness.
definitions.example: statesmen must be cognizant of the political boundaries within which they work

words.origin: mid 17th century: from late Latin commensuratus, from com- ‘together’ + mensuratus, past participle of mensurare ‘to measure’.

definitions.definition: corresponding in size or degree; in proportion.
definitions.example: salary will be commensurate with age and experience

words.origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘completion’): from Latin complementum, from complere ‘fill up’ (see complete). Compare with compliment.

definitions.definition: a thing that contributes extra features to something else in such a way as to improve or emphasize its quality.
definitions.example: local ales provide the perfect complement to fine food

definitions.definition: a number or quantity of something, especially that required to make a group complete.
definitions.example: at the moment we have a full complement of staff

definitions.definition: one or more words, phrases, or clauses governed by a verb (or by a nominalization or a predicative adjective) that complete the meaning of the predicate. In generative grammar, all the constituents of a sentence that are governed by a verb form the complement.
a group of proteins present in blood plasma and tissue fluid which combine with an antigen–antibody complex to bring about the lysis of foreign cells.
contribute extra features to (someone or something) in such a way as to improve or emphasize their qualities.
definitions.example: a classic blazer complements a look that's smart or casual

words.origin: Middle English: from Old French componction, from ecclesiastical Latin compunctio(n- ), from Latin compungere ‘prick sharply’, from com- (expressing intensive force) + pungere ‘to prick’.

definitions.definition: a feeling of guilt or moral scruple that prevents or follows the doing of something bad.
definitions.example: they used their tanks without compunction

words.origin: early 17th century: from late Latin concomitant- ‘accompanying’, from concomitari, from con- ‘together with’ + comitari, from Latin comes ‘companion’.

definitions.definition: naturally accompanying or associated.
definitions.example: she loved travel, with all its concomitant worries

definitions.definition: a phenomenon that naturally accompanies or follows something.
definitions.example: he sought promotion without the necessary concomitant of hard work

words.origin: Middle English: from Old French, from medieval Latin conductus, from Latin conducere ‘bring together’ (see conduct).

definitions.definition: a channel for conveying water or other fluid.
definitions.example: nearby springs supplied the conduit which ran into the brewery

definitions.definition: a tube or trough for protecting electric wiring.
definitions.example: the gas pipe should not be close to any electrical conduit

words.origin: late 15th century (denoting consumption by fire): from Latin conflagratio(n- ), from the verb conflagrare, from con- (expressing intensive force) + flagrare ‘to blaze’.

definitions.definition: an extensive fire which destroys a great deal of land or property.
definitions.example: tinder-dry conditions sparked fears of a conflagration in many drought-devastated communities

words.origin: early 17th century: from French conniver or Latin connivere ‘shut the eyes (to)’, from con- ‘together’ + an unrecorded word related to nictare ‘to wink’.

definitions.definition: secretly allow (something immoral, illegal, or harmful) to occur.
definitions.example: I did not connive in the production of these documents

words.origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘mark with the sign of the cross’, especially at baptism or confirmation, as a sign of dedication to God): from French consigner or Latin consignare ‘mark with a seal’.

definitions.definition: deliver (something) to a person's keeping.
definitions.example: he consigned three paintings to Sotheby's

words.origin: late 15th century (as a noun denoting a person who appoints another as agent): from Latin constituent- (partly via French constituant ) ‘establishing, appointing’, from the verb constituere (see constitute).

definitions.definition: being a part of a whole.
definitions.example: the constituent minerals of the rock

definitions.definition: being a voting member of an organization and having the power to appoint or elect.
definitions.example: the constituent body has a right of veto

definitions.definition: a member of an area which elects a representative to a legislative body.
definitions.example: the MP is playing on his constituents' sense of regional identity to win votes

definitions.definition: a component part of something.
definitions.example: the essential constituents of the human diet

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin construere (see construct), in late Latin ‘analyse the construction of a sentence’.

definitions.definition: interpret (a word or action) in a particular way.
definitions.example: his words could hardly be construed as an apology

definitions.definition: analyse the syntax of (a text, sentence, or word).
definitions.example: both verbs can be construed with either infinitive

words.origin: late Middle English: from French, from Latin contusio(n- ), from the verb contundere (see contuse).

definitions.definition: a region of injured tissue or skin in which blood capillaries have been ruptured; a bruise.
definitions.example: a dark contusion on his cheek was beginning to swell

words.origin: Middle English: from Old French contrit, from Latin contritus, past participle of conterere ‘grind down, wear away’, from con- ‘together’ + terere ‘rub’.

definitions.definition: feeling or expressing remorse at the recognition that one has done wrong.
definitions.example: a contrite tone

words.origin: late Middle English: from Old French contentieux, from Latin contentiosus, from content- ‘striven’, from the verb contendere .

definitions.definition: causing or likely to cause an argument; controversial.
definitions.example: a contentious issue

words.origin: mid 16th century: from late Latin contravenire, from Latin contra- ‘against’ + venire ‘come’.

definitions.definition: offend against the prohibition or order of (a law, treaty, or code of conduct).
definitions.example: he contravened the Official Secrets Act

words.origin: mid 17th century (in the sense ‘fit for a feast, festive’): from Latin convivialis, from convivium ‘a feast’, from con- ‘with’ + vivere ‘live’.

definitions.definition: (of an atmosphere or event) friendly, lively, and enjoyable.
definitions.example: a convivial cocktail party

definitions.definition: the state of being fat; obesity.
definitions.example: her corpulence is the butt of every joke

words.origin: Middle English: from Old French cuveitier, based on Latin cupiditas (see cupidity).

definitions.definition: yearn to possess (something, especially something belonging to another).
definitions.example: I covet one of their smart bags

words.origin: Middle English derthe  (see dear, -th2).

definitions.definition: a scarcity or lack of something.
definitions.example: there is a dearth of evidence

definitions.definition: expose the falseness or hollowness of (an idea or belief).
definitions.example: she debunks all the usual rubbish about acting

words.origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘blacken, make dark’): from Latin denigrat- ‘blackened’, from the verb denigrare, from de- ‘away, completely’ + nigrare (from niger ‘black’).

definitions.definition: criticize unfairly; disparage.
definitions.example: doom and gloom merchants who denigrate their own country

words.origin: late Middle English (in the adjective sense ‘having the power to draw off’, and in the noun sense ‘a word derived from another’): from French dérivatif, -ive, from Latin derivativus, from derivare (see derive).

definitions.definition: imitative of the work of another artist, writer, etc., and usually disapproved of for that reason.
definitions.example: an artist who is not in the slightest bit derivative

definitions.definition: (of a product) having a value deriving from an underlying variable asset.
definitions.example: equity-based derivative products

definitions.definition: something which is based on another source.
definitions.example: the aircraft is a derivative of the Falcon 20G

definitions.definition: an arrangement or product (such as a future, option, or warrant) whose value derives from and is dependent on the value of an underlying asset, such as a commodity, currency, or security.
definitions.example: the derivatives market

definitions.definition: an expression representing the rate of change of a function with respect to an independent variable.

words.origin: mid 16th century: from French despote, via medieval Latin from Greek despotēs ‘master, absolute ruler’. Originally (after the Turkish conquest of Constantinople) the term denoted a minor Christian ruler under the Turkish empire. The current sense dates from the late 18th century.

definitions.definition: a ruler or other person who holds absolute power, typically one who exercises it in a cruel or oppressive way.

words.origin: early 17th century: from medieval Latin diaphanus, from Greek diaphanēs, from dia ‘through’ + phainein ‘to show’.

definitions.definition: (especially of fabric) light, delicate, and translucent.
definitions.example: a diaphanous dress of pale gold

words.origin: mid 17th century: from Greek didaktikos, from didaskein ‘teach’.

definitions.definition: intended to teach, particularly in having moral instruction as an ulterior motive.
definitions.example: a didactic novel that set out to expose social injustice

words.origin: Middle English (denoting the Office for the Dead): from Latin dirige! (imperative) ‘direct!’, the first word of an antiphon (Ps. 5:8) formerly used in the Latin Office for the Dead.

definitions.definition: a lament for the dead, especially one forming part of a funeral rite.

words.origin: mid 17th century: past participle of disaffect, originally in the sense ‘dislike or disorder’, from dis- (expressing reversal) + affect2.

definitions.definition: dissatisfied, especially with people in authority or a system of control.
definitions.example: a military plot by disaffected elements in the army

words.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘defeat in battle’): from Old French desconfit, past participle of desconfire, based on Latin dis- (expressing reversal) + conficere ‘put together’ (see confection).

definitions.definition: make (someone) feel uneasy or embarrassed.
definitions.example: he was not noticeably discomfited by her tone

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin disparatus ‘separated’, from the verb disparare, from dis- ‘apart’ + parare ‘to prepare’; influenced in sense by Latin dispar ‘unequal’.

definitions.definition: essentially different in kind; not able to be compared.
definitions.example: they inhabit disparate worlds of thought

definitions.definition: things so unlike that there is no basis for comparison.

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin dispellere, from dis- ‘apart’ + pellere ‘to drive’.

definitions.definition: make (a doubt, feeling, or belief) disappear.
definitions.example: the brightness of the day did nothing to dispel Elaine's dejection

definitions.definition: the state of being held in low esteem by the public.
definitions.example: one of the top clubs in the country is bringing the game into disrepute

words.origin: early 17th century (as a noun denoting a philosopher or physician of a school based on a priori assumptions): via late Latin from Greek dogmatikos, from dogma, dogmat- (see dogma).

definitions.definition: inclined to lay down principles as undeniably true.
definitions.example: she was not tempted to be dogmatic about what she believed

words.origin: late Middle English (originally Scots): probably from Scottish Gaelic dúr ‘dull, obstinate, stupid’, perhaps from Latin durus ‘hard’.

definitions.definition: relentlessly severe, stern, or gloomy in manner or appearance.
definitions.example: a hard, dour, humourless fanatic

words.origin: late Middle English: from Old French duplicite or late Latin duplicitas, from Latin duplic- ‘twofold’ (see duplex).

definitions.definition: deceitfulness.
definitions.example: he was accused of duplicity and branded a traitor

definitions.definition: the state of being double.

words.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘harshness, severity, cruel treatment’): via Old French from Latin duritia, from durus ‘hard’.

definitions.definition: threats, violence, constraints, or other action used to coerce someone into doing something against their will or better judgement.
definitions.example: confessions extracted under duress

words.origin: late 17th century (as a term in philosophy): from Greek eklektikos, from eklegein ‘pick out’, from ek ‘out’ + legein ‘choose’.

definitions.definition: deriving ideas, style, or taste from a broad and diverse range of sources.
definitions.example: universities offering an eclectic mix of courses

definitions.definition: denoting or belonging to a class of ancient philosophers who did not belong to or found any recognized school of thought but selected doctrines from various schools of thought.
a person who derives ideas, style, or taste from a broad and diverse range of sources.

words.origin: Middle English: from Latin edictum ‘something proclaimed’, neuter past participle of edicere, from e- (variant of ex- ) ‘out’ + dicere ‘say, tell’.

definitions.definition: an official order or proclamation issued by a person in authority.
definitions.example: Clovis issued an edict protecting Church property

words.origin: late 16th century (in the sense ‘boiling’): from Latin ebullient- ‘boiling up’, from the verb ebullire, from e- (variant of ex- ) ‘out’ + bullire ‘to boil’.

definitions.definition: cheerful and full of energy.
definitions.example: she sounded ebullient and happy

definitions.definition: (of liquid or matter) boiling or agitated as if boiling.
definitions.example: misted and ebullient seas

words.origin: early 16th century: from French élégie, or via Latin, from Greek elegeia, from elegos ‘mournful poem’.

definitions.definition: (in modern literature) a poem of serious reflection, typically a lament for the dead.
(in Greek and Latin verse) a poem written in elegiac couplets, as notably by Catullus and Propertius.

words.origin: mid 17th century: from Latin elicit- ‘drawn out by trickery or magic’, from the verb elicere, from e- (variant of ex- ) ‘out’ + lacere ‘entice, deceive’.

definitions.definition: evoke or draw out (a reaction, answer, or fact) from someone.
definitions.example: I tried to elicit a smile from Joanna

definitions.definition: theft or misappropriation of funds placed in one's trust or belonging to one's employer.
definitions.example: charges of fraud and embezzlement

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin emendare, from e- (variant of ex- ) ‘out of’ + menda ‘a fault’. Compare with amend.

definitions.definition: make corrections and revisions to (a text).
definitions.example: these studies show him collating manuscripts and emending texts

words.origin: mid 17th century: from Latin emollient- ‘making soft’, from the verb emollire, from e- (variant of ex- ‘out’) + mollis ‘soft’.

definitions.definition: having the quality of softening or soothing the skin.
definitions.example: a rich emollient shampoo

definitions.definition: attempting to avoid confrontation or anger; calming or conciliatory.
definitions.example: the president's emollient approach to differences

definitions.definition: a preparation that softens the skin.
definitions.example: always moisturize exposed skin with an effective emollient

definitions.definition: based on, concerned with, or verifiable by observation or experience rather than theory or pure logic.
definitions.example: they provided considerable empirical evidence to support their argument

words.origin: late 16th century: from Latin aemulat- ‘rivalled, equalled’, from the verb aemulari, from aemulus ‘rival’.

definitions.definition: match or surpass (a person or achievement), typically by imitation.
definitions.example: most rulers wished to emulate Alexander the Great
synonyms: be in the same league as

words.origin: early 17th century: from Latin enervat- ‘weakened (by extraction of the sinews)’, from the verb enervare, from e- (variant of ex-) ‘out of’ + nervus ‘sinew’.

definitions.definition: make (someone) feel drained of energy or vitality.
definitions.example: the heat enervated us all

definitions.definition: lacking in energy or vitality.
definitions.example: the enervate slightness of his frail form

words.origin: late Middle English (formerly also as infranchise ): from Old French enfranchiss-, lengthened stem of enfranchir, from en- (expressing a change of state) + franc, franche ‘free’.

definitions.definition: give the right to vote to.
free (a slave).

words.origin: late 16th century: from Greek ephēmeros (see ephemera) + -al.

definitions.definition: lasting for a very short time.
definitions.example: fashions are ephemeral: new ones regularly drive out the old

definitions.definition: an ephemeral plant.
definitions.example: ephemerals avoid the periods of drought as seeds

words.origin: mid 17th century: from French épistolaire or Latin epistolaris, from epistola (see epistle).

definitions.definition: (of a literary work) in the form of letters.
definitions.example: an epistolary novel

words.origin: early 17th century (also in the sense ‘fairness, impartiality’): from Latin aequanimitas, from aequus ‘equal’ + animus ‘mind’.

definitions.definition: calmness and composure, especially in a difficult situation.
definitions.example: she accepted both the good and the bad with equanimity

words.origin: mid 16th century: from late Latin aequivocus, from Latin aequus ‘equally’ + vocare ‘to call’.

definitions.definition: open to more than one interpretation; ambiguous.
definitions.example: the equivocal nature of her remarks

words.origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘take as a spouse’): from Old French espouser, from Latin sponsare, from sponsus ‘betrothed’, past participle of spondere .

definitions.definition: adopt or support (a cause, belief, or way of life).
definitions.example: she espoused the causes of justice and freedom for all

definitions.definition: marry.
definitions.example: Edward had espoused the lady Grey

words.origin: early 18th century (in the sense ‘almost imperceptible’): from Latin evanescent- ‘disappearing’, from the verb evanescere (see evanesce).

definitions.definition: soon passing out of sight, memory, or existence; quickly fading or disappearing.
definitions.example: the evanescent Arctic summer

definitions.definition: denoting a field or wave which extends into a region where it cannot propagate and whose amplitude therefore decreases with distance.

words.origin: late 16th century (in the sense ‘prove by argument or evidence’): from Latin evincere ‘overcome, defeat’ (see evict).

definitions.definition: reveal the presence of (a quality or feeling); indicate.
definitions.example: the news stories evinced the usual mixture of sympathy and satisfaction

words.origin: late Middle English: from Old French exhorter or Latin exhortari, from ex- ‘thoroughly’ + hortari ‘encourage’.

definitions.definition: strongly encourage or urge (someone) to do something.
definitions.example: I exhorted her to be a good child

words.origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘expressing or involving a curse’): via Old French from Latin execrabilis, from exsecrari ‘to curse’ (see execrate).

definitions.definition: extremely bad or unpleasant.
definitions.example: execrable cheap wine

words.origin: early 17th century: from Latin exigent- ‘completing, ascertaining’, from the verb exigere (see exact).

definitions.definition: pressing; demanding.
definitions.example: the exigent demands of her contemporaries' music took a toll on her voice

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin expedient- ‘extricating, putting in order’, from the verb expedire (see expedite).

definitions.definition: (of an action) convenient and practical although possibly improper or immoral.
definitions.example: either side could break the agreement if it were expedient to do so
