definitions.definition: a means of attaining an end, especially one that is convenient but possibly improper or immoral.
definitions.example: the current policy is a political expedient

words.origin: late 16th century (in the sense ‘end (rage, sorrow, etc.) by suffering it to the full’): from Latin expiat- ‘appeased by sacrifice’, from the verb expiare, from ex- ‘out’ + piare (from pius ‘pious’).

definitions.definition: make amends or reparation for (guilt or wrongdoing).
definitions.example: their sins must be expiated by sacrifice

words.origin: early 17th century: from Latin expungere ‘mark for deletion by means of points’, from ex- ‘out’ + pungere ‘to prick’.

definitions.definition: obliterate or remove completely (something unwanted or unpleasant).
definitions.example: the kind of man that could expunge an unsatisfactory incident from his memory

words.origin: mid 17th century: from Latin extraneus + -ous.

definitions.definition: irrelevant or unrelated to the subject being dealt with.
definitions.example: one is obliged to wade through many pages of extraneous material

definitions.definition: of external origin.
definitions.example: when the transmitter pack is turned off no extraneous noise is heard

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin extollere, from ex- ‘out, upward’ + tollere ‘raise’.

definitions.definition: praise enthusiastically.
definitions.example: he extolled the virtues of the Russian peoples

words.origin: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘able to be publicly seen or reached’): from Latin exstant- ‘being visible or prominent, existing’, from the verb exstare, from ex- ‘out’ + stare ‘to stand’.

definitions.definition: still in existence; surviving.
definitions.example: an extant letter

words.origin: early 17th century (in the sense ‘purge of excrement’): from Latin expurgat- ‘thoroughly cleansed’, from the verb expurgare, from ex- ‘out’ + purgare ‘cleanse’.

definitions.definition: remove matter thought to be objectionable or unsuitable from (a text or account).
definitions.example: editors heavily expurgated the novel before its initial publication

words.origin: late 15th century: from Old French fallacieux, from Latin fallaciosus, from fallacia (see fallacy).

definitions.definition: based on a mistaken belief.
definitions.example: fallacious arguments

words.origin: early 17th century: from Latin fatuus ‘foolish’ + -ous.

definitions.definition: silly and pointless.
definitions.example: a fatuous comment

words.origin: Old English feter, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch veter ‘a lace’, from an Indo-European root shared by foot.

definitions.definition: a chain or manacle used to restrain a prisoner, typically placed around the ankles.
definitions.example: he lay bound with fetters of iron

definitions.definition: restrain with chains or manacles, typically around the ankles.
definitions.example: there were no chains immediately available to fetter the prisoners

words.origin: late 15th century (in the sense ‘blazing, resplendent’): from French, or from Latin flagrant- ‘blazing’, from the verb flagrare .

definitions.definition: (of an action considered wrong or immoral) conspicuously or obviously offensive.
definitions.example: a flagrant violation of the law

words.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘trample down’): perhaps from Old French fouler ‘to full cloth, trample’, based on Latin fullo ‘fuller’. Compare with full2.

definitions.definition: prevent (something considered wrong or undesirable) from succeeding.
definitions.example: a brave policewoman foiled the armed robbery

definitions.definition: the track or scent of a hunted animal.
a setback in an enterprise; a defeat.
patient self-control; restraint and tolerance.
definitions.example: his unfailing courtesy and forbearance under great provocation

words.origin: mid 17th century: from Latin fortuitus, from forte ‘by chance’, from fors ‘chance, luck’.

definitions.definition: happening by chance rather than intention.
definitions.example: the similarity between the paintings may not be simply fortuitous

words.origin: late 17th century: from fraction, probably on the pattern of the pair faction, factious .

definitions.definition: (typically of children) irritable and quarrelsome.
definitions.example: they fight and squabble like fractious children
synonyms: like a bear with a sore head

words.origin: early 17th century: from Latin garrulus (from garrire ‘to chatter, prattle’) + -ous.

definitions.definition: excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.
definitions.example: a garrulous cab driver
synonyms: with the gift of the gab

words.origin: late Middle English: from Old French, of unknown origin.

definitions.definition: a person who enjoys eating and often eats too much.

words.origin: late 16th century: from Latin grandiloquus, literally ‘grand-speaking’, from grandis ‘grand’ + loqui ‘speak’. The ending was altered in English by association with eloquent.

definitions.definition: pompous or extravagant in language, style, or manner, especially in a way that is intended to impress.
definitions.example: a grandiloquent celebration of Spanish glory

words.origin: mid 17th century: from Latin gratuitus ‘given freely, spontaneous’ + -ous.

definitions.definition: done without good reason; uncalled for.
definitions.example: gratuitous violence

definitions.definition: given or done free of charge.
definitions.example: solicitors provide a form of gratuitous legal advice

words.origin: late Middle English: from hap1 (in the early sense ‘good fortune’) + -less.

definitions.definition: (especially of a person) unfortunate.
definitions.example: the hapless victims of the disaster

words.origin: mid 16th century: from Greek hēgemonia, from hēgemōn ‘leader’, from hēgeisthai ‘to lead’.

definitions.definition: leadership or dominance, especially by one state or social group over others.
definitions.example: Germany was united under Prussian hegemony after 1871

words.origin: mid 17th century (in iconoclast (sense 2)): via medieval Latin from ecclesiastical Greek eikonoklastēs, from eikōn ‘likeness’ + klan ‘to break’.

definitions.definition: a person who attacks or criticizes cherished beliefs or institutions.
a destroyer of images used in religious worship.

words.origin: late 18th century: from idiosyncrasy, on the pattern of Greek sunkratikos ‘mixed together’.

definitions.definition: relating to idiosyncrasy; peculiar or individual.
definitions.example: she emerged as one of the great, idiosyncratic talents of the nineties

words.origin: late 16th century: from in-1 ‘not’ + obsolete pecunious ‘having money, wealthy’ (from Latin pecuniosus, from pecunia ‘money’).

definitions.definition: having little or no money.
definitions.example: a titled but impecunious family

words.origin: late Middle English: from Old French impetueux, from late Latin impetuosus, from impetere ‘to attack’.

definitions.definition: acting or done quickly and without thought or care.
definitions.example: she might live to rue this impetuous decision

words.origin: late Middle English: from Old French imputer, from Latin imputare ‘enter in the account’, from in- ‘in, towards’ + putare ‘reckon’.

definitions.definition: represent (something, especially something undesirable) as being done or possessed by someone; attribute.
definitions.example: the crimes imputed to Richard

definitions.definition: assign (a value) to something by inference from the value of the products or processes to which it contributes.
definitions.example: by imputing the interest rates they potentially introduce a measurement error

words.origin: mid 16th century: from Latin inanis ‘empty, vain’.

definitions.definition: lacking sense or meaning; silly.
definitions.example: don't badger people with inane questions

words.origin: mid 16th century: from Latin inchoatus, past participle of inchoare, variant of incohare ‘begin’.

definitions.definition: just begun and so not fully formed or developed; rudimentary.
definitions.example: a still inchoate democracy

definitions.definition: (of an offence, such as incitement or conspiracy) anticipating or preparatory to a further criminal act.
not able to be denied or disputed.
definitions.example: incontrovertible proof
synonyms: beyond a shadow of a doubt

words.origin: late Middle English (as a noun): from Anglo-Latin incumbens, incumbent-, from Latin incumbere ‘lie or lean on’, from in- ‘upon’ + a verb related to cubare ‘lie’.

definitions.definition: necessary for (someone) as a duty or responsibility.
definitions.example: the government realized that it was incumbent on them to act

definitions.definition: (of an official or regime) currently holding office.
definitions.example: the incumbent President was defeated

definitions.definition: (of a company) having a sizeable share of a market.
definitions.example: powerful incumbent airlines

definitions.definition: the holder of an office or post.
definitions.example: the present incumbent will soon be retiring

words.origin: mid 16th century: from French, or from Latin inexorabilis, from in- ‘not’ + exorabilis (from exorare ‘entreat’).

definitions.definition: impossible to stop or prevent.
definitions.example: the seemingly inexorable march of new technology

words.origin: early 16th century: from late Latin inimicalis, from Latin inimicus (see enemy).

definitions.definition: tending to obstruct or harm.
definitions.example: the policy was inimical to Britain's real interests

words.origin: late Middle English: from late Latin injunctio(n- ), from Latin injungere ‘enjoin, impose’.

definitions.definition: an authoritative warning or order.

words.origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘graft a bud or shoot into a different plant’): from Latin inoculat- ‘engrafted’, from the verb inoculare, from in- ‘into’ + oculus ‘eye, bud’. The sense ‘vaccinate’ dates from the early 18th century.

definitions.definition: treat with a vaccine to produce immunity against a disease; vaccinate.
definitions.example: he inoculated his tenants against smallpox

words.origin: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘urge on’): from Latin instigat- ‘urged, incited’, from the verb instigare, from in- ‘towards’ + stigare ‘prick, incite’.

definitions.definition: bring about or initiate (an action or event).
definitions.example: they instigated a reign of terror

words.origin: mid 18th century: via French from Latin insurgent- ‘arising’, from the verb insurgere, from in- ‘into, towards’ + surgere ‘to rise’.

definitions.definition: a person fighting against a government or invading force; a rebel or revolutionary.
definitions.example: an attack by armed insurgents

definitions.definition: rising in active revolt.
definitions.example: alleged links with insurgent groups

words.origin: early 16th century: modern Latin, from Latin interlocut- ‘interrupted (by speech)’, from the verb interloqui, from inter- ‘between’ + loqui ‘speak’.

definitions.definition: a person who takes part in a dialogue or conversation.
an indication or hint.
definitions.example: the first intimations of trouble

words.origin: late Middle English inure, enure, from an Anglo-Norman French phrase meaning ‘in use or practice’, from en ‘in’ + Old French euvre ‘work’ (from Latin opera ).

definitions.definition: accustom (someone) to something, especially something unpleasant.
definitions.example: these children have been inured to violence

definitions.definition: variant spelling of enure (sense 1).

words.origin: late Middle English (originally as an adjective meaning ‘reviling, abusive’): from Old French invectif, -ive, from late Latin invectivus ‘attacking’, from invehere (see inveigh). The noun is from late Latin invectiva (oratio) ‘abusive or censorious (language)’.

definitions.definition: insulting, abusive, or highly critical language.
definitions.example: he let out a stream of invective

words.origin: late 19th century: from French intransigeant, from Spanish los intransigentes (a name adopted by the extreme republicans in the Cortes, 1873–4); based on Latin in- ‘not’ + transigere ‘come to an understanding’.

definitions.definition: unwilling or refusing to change one's views or to agree about something.
definitions.example: her father had tried persuasion, but she was intransigent

definitions.definition: an intransigent person.

words.origin: late Middle English (referring to disease, in the sense ‘of long standing, chronic’): from Latin inveteratus ‘made old’, past participle of inveterare (based on vetus, veter- ‘old’).

definitions.definition: having a particular habit, activity, or interest that is long-established and unlikely to change.
definitions.example: an inveterate gambler

definitions.definition: a lack of respect for people or things that are generally taken seriously.
definitions.example: an attitude of irreverence towards politicians

words.origin: Old English cnyll (noun), cnyllan (verb), of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch knal (noun), knallen (verb) ‘bang, pop, crack’. The current spelling (dating from the 16th century) is perhaps influenced by bell1.

definitions.definition: the sound of a bell, especially when rung solemnly for a death or funeral.
(of a bell) ring solemnly, especially for a death or funeral.

words.origin: Middle English: from Old French, from Latin largus ‘copious’.

definitions.definition: generosity in bestowing money or gifts upon others.
definitions.example: presumably public money is not dispensed with such largesse to anyone else

words.origin: late Middle English: from French léger de main ‘dexterous’, literally ‘light of hand’.

definitions.definition: skilful use of one's hands when performing conjuring tricks.

words.origin: late 18th century (in libertarian (sense 3 of the noun)): from liberty, on the pattern of words such as unitarian .

definitions.definition: an advocate or supporter of a political philosophy that advocates only minimal state intervention in the free market and the private lives of citizens.
definitions.example: no true libertarian would ever support a culture where citizens must show their papers to travel

definitions.definition: a person who advocates civil liberty.
a person who believes in the doctrine that human beings possess free will.
relating to or denoting a political philosophy that advocates only minimal state intervention in the free market and the private lives of citizens.
definitions.example: he holds libertarian views on most social issues

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin licentiosus, from licentia ‘freedom’.

definitions.definition: promiscuous and unprincipled in sexual matters.
definitions.example: the ruler's tyrannical and licentious behaviour

definitions.definition: disregarding accepted conventions, especially in grammar or literary style.

words.origin: late Middle English: from Old English lynis (in the sense ‘linchpin’) + pin.

definitions.definition: a person or thing vital to an enterprise or organization.
definitions.example: nurses are the linchpin of the National Health Service

definitions.definition: a pin passed through the end of an axle to keep a wheel in position.

words.origin: mid 17th century: from French, from Latin litigant- ‘carrying on a lawsuit’, from the verb litigare (see litigate).

definitions.definition: a person involved in a lawsuit.
involved in a lawsuit.
definitions.example: the parties litigant

words.origin: late 17th century: from early modern Dutch (denoting a mythical whirlpool in the Arctic Ocean, west of Norway), from maalen ‘grind, whirl’ + stroom ‘stream’.

definitions.definition: a powerful whirlpool in the sea or a river.

words.origin: late Middle English (as a noun denoting Mary Magdalen): from Old French Madeleine, from Church Latin Magdalena (see magdalen). The current sense derives from allusion to pictures of Mary Magdalen weeping.

definitions.definition: self-pityingly or tearfully sentimental.
definitions.example: a bout of maudlin self-pity

words.origin: mid 19th century: from the name of Samuel A. Maverick (1803–70), a Texas rancher who did not brand his cattle.

definitions.definition: an unorthodox or independent-minded person.
an unbranded calf or yearling.
unorthodox.
definitions.example: a maverick detective

words.origin: mid 17th century (in the sense ‘inclined to sickness’): from obsolete mawk ‘maggot’, from Old Norse mathkr, of Germanic origin.

definitions.definition: sentimental in an exaggerated or false way.
definitions.example: a mawkish ode to parenthood

words.origin: late Middle English (denoting an axiom): from French maxime, from medieval Latin (propositio) maxima ‘largest or most important (proposition)’.

definitions.definition: a short, pithy statement expressing a general truth or rule of conduct.
definitions.example: the maxim that actions speak louder than words

words.origin: early 17th century: from Latin mendax, mendac- ‘lying’ (related to mendum ‘fault’) + -ious.

definitions.definition: not telling the truth; lying.
definitions.example: mendacious propaganda

words.origin: late 15th century: from Latin, neuter of modicus ‘moderate’, from modus ‘measure’.

definitions.definition: a small quantity of a particular thing, especially something desirable or valuable.
definitions.example: his statement had a modicum of truth

words.origin: late 15th century: from Dutch moeras, alteration (by assimilation to moer ‘moor’) of Middle Dutch marasch, from Old French marais ‘marsh’, from medieval Latin mariscus .

definitions.definition: an area of muddy or boggy ground.
definitions.example: in midwinter the track beneath this bridge became a muddy morass

definitions.definition: a complicated or confused situation.
definitions.example: she would become lost in a morass of lies and explanations

words.origin: late 19th century: from Latin, plural of mos, mor- ‘custom’.

definitions.definition: the essential or characteristic customs and conventions of a society or community.
definitions.example: an offence against social mores

words.origin: late 16th century: from Latin munificent- (stem of munificentior, comparative of munificus ‘bountiful’), from munus ‘gift’.

definitions.definition: characterized by or displaying great generosity.
definitions.example: a munificent bequest

words.origin: late 16th century: from Latin multifarius + -ous.

definitions.definition: many and of various types.
definitions.example: multifarious activities

words.origin: late Middle English (in nadir (sense 2 of the noun)): via French from Arabic naẓīr (as-samt) ‘opposite (to the zenith)’.

definitions.definition: the lowest or most unsuccessful point in a situation.
definitions.example: asking that question was the nadir of my career
synonyms: as low as one can get

definitions.definition: the point on the celestial sphere directly below an observer.
failing to take proper care over something.
definitions.example: the council had been negligent in its supervision of the children in care

words.origin: late Middle English: via ecclesiastical Latin from Greek neophutos, literally ‘newly planted’ but first used in the sense ‘new convert’ by St Paul (1 Tim. 3:6), from neos ‘new’ + phuton ‘plant’.

definitions.definition: a person who is new to a subject or activity.
definitions.example: four-day cooking classes are offered to neophytes and experts

definitions.definition: a new convert to a religion.

words.origin: late Middle English: from obsolete noy (shortened form of annoy) + -some1.

definitions.definition: having an extremely offensive smell.
definitions.example: noisome vapours from the smouldering waste

words.origin: late 15th century: from Latin noxius (from noxa ‘harm’) + -ous.

definitions.definition: harmful, poisonous, or very unpleasant.
definitions.example: they were overcome by the noxious fumes

words.origin: late Middle English (originally in the sense ‘hardened in sin, impenitent’): from Latin obduratus, past participle of obdurare, from ob- ‘in opposition’ + durare ‘harden’ (from durus ‘hard’).

definitions.definition: stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or course of action.
definitions.example: I argued this point with him, but he was obdurate

words.origin: late Middle English: from late Latin obfuscat- ‘darkened’, from the verb obfuscare, based on Latin fuscus ‘dark’.

definitions.definition: make obscure, unclear, or unintelligible.
definitions.example: the spelling changes will deform some familiar words and obfuscate their etymological origins

words.origin: late 16th century (in the sense ‘clamorous, vociferous’): from Latin obstreperus (from obstrepere, from ob- ‘against’ + strepere ‘make a noise’) + -ous.

definitions.definition: noisy and difficult to control.
definitions.example: the boy is cocky and obstreperous

words.origin: late 15th century: from Latin officiosus ‘obliging’, from officium (see office). The original sense was ‘performing its function, efficacious’, whence ‘ready to help or please’ (mid 16th century), later becoming depreciatory (late 16th century).

definitions.definition: assertive of authority in a domineering way, especially with regard to trivial matters.
definitions.example: the security people were very officious

words.origin: late Middle English: from Old French onereus, from Latin onerosus, from onus, oner- ‘burden’.

definitions.definition: (of a task or responsibility) involving a great deal of effort, trouble, or difficulty.
definitions.example: he found his duties increasingly onerous

words.origin: mid 18th century: from French, from medieval Latin ostensibilis from Latin ostens- ‘stretched out to view’, from the verb ostendere, from ob- ‘in view of’ + tendere ‘to stretch’.

definitions.definition: stated or appearing to be true, but not necessarily so.
definitions.example: the real dispute which lay behind the ostensible complaint

definitions.definition: exclusion from a society or group.
definitions.example: the family suffered social ostracism

definitions.definition: (in ancient Greece) temporary banishment from a city by popular vote.
definitions.example: the ostracism of Thucydides

words.origin: late Middle English: from late Latin palliat- ‘cloaked’, from the verb palliare, from pallium ‘cloak’.

definitions.definition: make (a disease or its symptoms) less severe without removing the cause.
definitions.example: treatment works by palliating symptoms

definitions.definition: disguise the seriousness of (an offence).
definitions.example: there is no way to excuse or palliate his dirty deed

words.origin: mid 16th century: via Latin from Greek panakeia, from panakēs ‘all-healing’, from pan ‘all’ + akos ‘remedy’.

definitions.definition: a solution or remedy for all difficulties or diseases.
definitions.example: the panacea for all corporate ills

words.origin: late 15th century: via late Latin from Greek paradeigma, from paradeiknunai ‘show side by side’, from para- ‘beside’ + deiknunai ‘to show’.

definitions.definition: a typical example or pattern of something; a pattern or model.
definitions.example: society's paradigm of the ‘ideal woman’

definitions.definition: a set of linguistic items that form mutually exclusive choices in particular syntactic roles.
definitions.example: English determiners form a paradigm: we can say ‘a book’ or ‘his book’ but not ‘a his book’

definitions.definition: (in the traditional grammar of Latin, Greek, and other inflected languages) a table of all the inflected forms of a particular verb, noun, or adjective, serving as a model for other words of the same conjugation or declension.

words.origin: early 17th century: from Tamil paṛaiyar, plural of paṛaiyan ‘(hereditary) drummer’, from paṛai ‘a drum’.

definitions.definition: an outcast.
definitions.example: they were treated as social pariahs

definitions.definition: a member of an indigenous people of southern India originally functioning as ceremonial drummers but later having a low caste.

words.origin: mid 16th century: from French, via Italian dialect from Italian partigiano, from parte ‘part’ (from Latin pars, part- ).

definitions.definition: a strong supporter of a party, cause, or person.
definitions.example: partisans of the exiled Stuarts

definitions.definition: a member of an armed group formed to fight secretly against an occupying force, in particular one operating in German-occupied Yugoslavia, Italy, and parts of eastern Europe in the Second World War.
definitions.example: the partisans opened fire from the woods

definitions.definition: prejudiced in favour of a particular cause.
definitions.example: newspapers have become increasingly partisan

words.origin: late Middle English: from Old French paucite or Latin paucitas, from paucus ‘few’.

definitions.definition: the presence of something in only small or insufficient quantities or amounts.
definitions.example: a paucity of information

words.origin: late 19th century: from French péjoratif, -ive, from late Latin pejorare ‘make worse’, from Latin pejor ‘worse’.

definitions.definition: expressing contempt or disapproval.
definitions.example: permissiveness is used almost universally as a pejorative term

definitions.definition: a word expressing contempt or disapproval.
definitions.example: most of what he said was inflammatory and filled with pejoratives

words.origin: early 17th century: from Latin pellucidus, from perlucere ‘shine through’.

definitions.definition: translucently clear.
definitions.example: mountains reflected in the pellucid waters

words.origin: late 17th century: from French, ‘leaning, inclining’, present participle of the verb pencher .

definitions.definition: a strong or habitual liking for something or tendency to do something.
definitions.example: he has a penchant for adopting stray dogs

words.origin: late 16th century: from medieval Latin penuriosus, from Latin penuria ‘need, scarcity’ (see penury).

definitions.definition: extremely poor; poverty-stricken.
definitions.example: a penurious old tramp
synonyms: as poor as a church mouse

definitions.definition: unwilling to spend money; mean.
definitions.example: a tight-fisted, penurious boss whose wage scale is well below other bandleaders

words.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘manifest’): from Old French apert, from Latin apertus ‘opened’, past participle of aperire, reinforced by Old French aspert, from Latin expertus (see expert).

definitions.definition: (of a girl or young woman) attractively lively or cheeky.
definitions.example: a pert, slightly plump girl called Rose

definitions.definition: (of a bodily feature or garment) attractively small and well shaped.
definitions.example: she had a pert nose and deep blue eyes

words.origin: early 17th century: from Latin pertinax, pertinac- ‘holding fast’ + -ous.

definitions.definition: holding firmly to an opinion or a course of action.
definitions.example: he worked with a pertinacious resistance to interruptions

words.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘relating to the humour phlegm’): from Old French fleumatique, via Latin from Greek phlegmatikos, from phlegma ‘inflammation’ (see phlegm).

definitions.definition: (of a person) having an unemotional and stolidly calm disposition.
definitions.example: the phlegmatic British character

words.origin: late 18th century: from French philanthropique, from Greek philanthrōpos ‘man-loving’ (see philanthrope).

definitions.definition: (of a person or organization) seeking to promote the welfare of others; generous and benevolent.
definitions.example: they receive financial support from philanthropic bodies

definitions.definition: (of a fruit or plant) containing much pith.
(of language or style) terse and vigorously expressive.
definitions.example: his characteristically pithy comments

words.origin: early 19th century: from French, from plat ‘flat’.

definitions.definition: a remark or statement, especially one with a moral content, that has been used too often to be interesting or thoughtful.
definitions.example: he masks his disdain for her with platitudes about how she should believe in herself more

words.origin: early 17th century: shortened from Latin plaudite ‘applaud!’ (said by Roman actors at the end of a play), imperative plural of plaudere .

definitions.definition: an expression of praise or approval.
definitions.example: the network has received plaudits for its sports coverage

words.origin: late Middle English: from Old French, from late Latin plenitudo, from plenus ‘full’.

definitions.definition: an abundance.
definitions.example: an ancient Celtic god thought to bring a plenitude of wealth or food

words.origin: late 16th century: from Latin portentum ‘omen, token’, from the verb portendere (see portend).

definitions.definition: a sign or warning that a momentous or calamitous event is likely to happen.
definitions.example: many birds are regarded as being portents of death

definitions.definition: an exceptional or wonderful person or thing.
definitions.example: what portent can be greater than a pious notary?

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin potentatus ‘dominion’, from potent- ‘being able or powerful’ (see potent1).

definitions.definition: a monarch or ruler, especially an autocratic one.

words.origin: late 15th century (in the sense ‘bar a route or passage’): from Latin praecludere, from prae ‘before’ + claudere ‘to shut’.

definitions.definition: prevent from happening; make impossible.
definitions.example: the secret nature of his work precluded official recognition

words.origin: mid 18th century: from French prédilection, from Latin praedilect- ‘preferred’, from the verb praediligere, from prae ‘in advance’ + diligere ‘to select’.

definitions.definition: a preference or special liking for something; a bias in favour of something.
definitions.example: my predilection for Asian food

definitions.definition: the quality or fact of being greater in number, quantity, or importance.
definitions.example: the preponderance of women among older people

words.origin: late Middle English (as a noun): via French from Latin praesagium, from praesagire ‘forebode’, from prae ‘before’ + sagire ‘perceive keenly’.

definitions.definition: be a sign or warning of (an imminent event, typically an unwelcome one).
definitions.example: the heavy clouds above the moorland presaged snow

definitions.definition: an omen or portent.
definitions.example: the fever was a sombre presage of his final illness

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin probitas, from probus ‘good’.

definitions.definition: the quality of having strong moral principles; honesty and decency.
definitions.example: financial probity

words.origin: late 16th century: from Latin proclivitas, from proclivis ‘inclined’, from pro- ‘forward, down’ + clivus ‘slope’.

definitions.definition: a tendency to choose or do something regularly; an inclination or predisposition towards a particular thing.
definitions.example: a proclivity for hard work

words.origin: mid 16th century (in the sense ‘overthrown, routed’): from Latin profligatus ‘dissolute’, past participle of profligare ‘overthrow, ruin’, from pro- ‘forward, down’ + fligere ‘strike down’.

definitions.definition: recklessly extravagant or wasteful in the use of resources.
definitions.example: profligate consumers of energy

definitions.definition: licentious; dissolute.
definitions.example: he succumbed to drink and a profligate lifestyle

definitions.definition: a licentious, dissolute person.
definitions.example: he is a drunkard and a profligate

words.origin: mid 16th century (earlier (late 15th century) as promulgation ): from Latin promulgat- ‘exposed to public view’, from the verb promulgare, from pro- ‘out, publicly’ + mulgere ‘cause to come forth’ (literally ‘to milk’).

definitions.definition: promote or make widely known (an idea or cause).
definitions.example: these objectives have to be promulgated within the organization

words.origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘to outlaw’): from Latin proscribere, from pro- ‘in front of’ + scribere ‘write’.

definitions.definition: forbid, especially by law.
definitions.example: strikes remained proscribed in the armed forces

words.origin: late 16th century: from Proteus + -an.

definitions.definition: tending or able to change frequently or easily.
definitions.example: it is difficult to comprehend the whole of this protean subject

words.origin: late 16th century (in the sense ‘having a mental itching’): from Latin prurient- ‘itching, longing’ and ‘being wanton’, from the verb prurire .

definitions.definition: having or encouraging an excessive interest in sexual matters, especially the sexual activity of others.
definitions.example: she'd been the subject of much prurient curiosity

words.origin: late 16th century (in the sense ‘like a boy’): from French puéril or Latin puerilis, from puer ‘boy’.

definitions.definition: childishly silly and immature.
definitions.example: a puerile argument

words.origin: mid 17th century: from Latin pugnax, pugnac- (from pugnare ‘to fight’, from pugnus ‘fist’) + -ious.

definitions.definition: eager or quick to argue, quarrel, or fight.
definitions.example: his public statements became increasingly pugnacious

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin pulchritudo, from pulcher, pulchr- ‘beautiful’.

definitions.definition: beauty.
definitions.example: the irresistible pulchritude of her friend

words.origin: mid 17th century: from French pointilleux, from pointille, from Italian puntiglio (see punctilio).

definitions.definition: showing great attention to detail or correct behaviour.
definitions.example: he was punctilious in providing every amenity for his guests

words.origin: Middle English: from Old French cointe, from Latin cognitus ‘ascertained’, past participle of cognoscere . The original sense was ‘wise, clever’, also ‘ingenious, cunningly devised’, hence ‘out of the ordinary’ and the current sense (late 18th century).

definitions.definition: attractively unusual or old-fashioned.
definitions.example: quaint country cottages

words.origin: late 18th century: from Don Quixote + -ic.

definitions.definition: extremely idealistic; unrealistic and impractical.
definitions.example: a vast and perhaps quixotic project

words.origin: late 16th century: perhaps partly from Latin quando ‘when’.

definitions.definition: a state of perplexity or uncertainty over what to do in a difficult situation.
definitions.example: Kate was in a quandary

words.origin: mid 19th century: from Latin recalcitrant- ‘kicking out with the heels’, from the verb recalcitrare, based on calx, calc- ‘heel’.

definitions.definition: having an obstinately uncooperative attitude towards authority or discipline.
definitions.example: a class of recalcitrant fifteen-year-olds

definitions.definition: a person with an obstinately uncooperative attitude.
definitions.example: a stiff-necked recalcitrant and troublemaker

words.origin: late Middle English: from Old French redoutable, from redouter ‘to fear’, from re- (expressing intensive force) + douter ‘to doubt’.

definitions.definition: (of a person) formidable, especially as an opponent.
definitions.example: he was a redoubtable debater

words.origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘send into exile’): from Latin relegat- ‘sent away, referred’, from the verb relegare, from re- ‘again’ + legare ‘send’.

definitions.definition: assign an inferior rank or position to.
definitions.example: they aim to prevent women from being relegated to a secondary role

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin remissus ‘slackened’, past participle of remittere . The early senses were ‘weakened in colour or consistency’ and (in describing sound) ‘faint, soft’.

definitions.definition: lacking care or attention to duty; negligent.
definitions.example: it would be very remiss of me not to pass on that information

words.origin: late 15th century (as the past participle repryed ): from Anglo-Norman French repris, past participle of reprendre, from Latin re- ‘back’ + prehendere ‘seize’. The insertion of -v- (16th century) remains unexplained. Sense development has undergone a reversal, from the early meaning ‘send back to prison’, via ‘postpone a legal process’, to the current sense ‘rescue from impending punishment’.

definitions.definition: cancel or postpone the punishment of (someone, especially someone condemned to death).
definitions.example: under the new regime, prisoners under sentence of death were reprieved
synonyms: grant a stay of execution to

definitions.definition: a cancellation or postponement of a punishment.
definitions.example: he accepted the death sentence and refused to appeal for a reprieve

words.origin: late Middle English (as a verb): from Latin reprobat- ‘disapproved’, from the verb reprobare, from re- (expressing reversal) + probare ‘approve’.

definitions.definition: an unprincipled person.
definitions.example: he had to present himself as more of a lovable reprobate than a spirit of corruption

definitions.definition: (in Calvinism) a sinner who is not of the elect and is predestined to damnation.
unprincipled.
definitions.example: reprobate behaviour

definitions.definition: (in Calvinism) predestined to damnation.
express or feel disapproval of.
definitions.example: his neighbours reprobated his method of proceeding

words.origin: mid 16th century: from Latin rescindere, from re- (expressing intensive force) + scindere ‘to divide, split’.

definitions.definition: revoke, cancel, or repeal (a law, order, or agreement).

words.origin: late Middle English (as a noun in the sense ‘request, demand’): from Old French, or from Latin requisitio(n- ), from requirere ‘search for’ (see require). The verb dates from the mid 19th century.

definitions.definition: an official order laying claim to the use of property or materials.
definitions.example: I had to make various requisitions for staff and accommodation

definitions.definition: demand the use or supply of (something) by official order.

words.origin: late Old English rȳfe, probably from Old Norse rīfr ‘acceptable’.

definitions.definition: (especially of something undesirable) of common occurrence; widespread.
definitions.example: male chauvinism was rife in medicine

definitions.definition: in an unchecked or widespread manner.
definitions.example: speculation ran rife that he was an arms dealer

words.origin: early 17th century (in the sense ‘holy in character’): from Latin sanctimonia ‘sanctity’ (from sanctus ‘holy’) + -ous.

definitions.definition: making a show of being morally superior to other people.
definitions.example: what happened to all the sanctimonious talk about putting his family first?

words.origin: Middle English: from Old French sanguin(e ) ‘blood red’, from Latin sanguineus ‘of blood’, from sanguis, sanguin- ‘blood’.

definitions.definition: optimistic or positive, especially in an apparently bad or difficult situation.
definitions.example: he is sanguine about prospects for the global economy

definitions.definition: blood-red.
bloody or bloodthirsty.
a blood-red colour.

words.origin: late 16th century: from French scurrile or Latin scurrilus (from scurra ‘buffoon’) + -ous.

definitions.definition: making or spreading scandalous claims about someone with the intention of damaging their reputation.
definitions.example: a scurrilous attack on his integrity

words.origin: early 19th century (denoting a signalling apparatus): from French sémaphore, formed irregularly from Greek sēma ‘sign’ + -phoros .

definitions.definition: a system of sending messages by holding the arms or two flags or poles in certain positions according to an alphabetic code.
definitions.example: if you learn semaphore or the Morse code, you'll have a fun way to send messages

definitions.definition: send (a message) by semaphore or by signals resembling semaphore.
definitions.example: Josh stands facing the rear and semaphoring the driver's intentions to frustrated queues of following cars

words.origin: 1754: coined by Horace Walpole, suggested by The Three Princes of Serendip, the title of a fairy tale in which the heroes ‘were always making discoveries, by accidents and sagacity, of things they were not in quest of’.

definitions.definition: the occurrence and development of events by chance in a happy or beneficial way.
definitions.example: a fortunate stroke of serendipity

words.origin: late Middle English: from Old French sobriete or Latin sobrietas, from sobrius (see sober).

definitions.definition: the state of being sober.
definitions.example: the price of beer compelled me to maintain a certain level of sobriety

definitions.definition: the quality of being staid or solemn.
definitions.example: she speaks with such sobriety, it's clear she speaks the truth

words.origin: mid 16th century: from Latin sollicitus (see solicit) + -ous.

definitions.definition: characterized by or showing interest or concern.
definitions.example: she was always solicitous about the welfare of her students

words.origin: late 19th century: from Latin solus ‘alone’ + ipse ‘self’ + -ism.

definitions.definition: the view or theory that the self is all that can be known to exist.

words.origin: late 16th century (in the sense ‘born out of wedlock’): from Latin spurius ‘false’ + -ous.

definitions.definition: not being what it purports to be; false or fake.
definitions.example: separating authentic and spurious claims

words.origin: mid 16th century: archaic past participle of stay1.

definitions.definition: sedate, respectable, and unadventurous.
definitions.example: staid law firms

words.origin: late 16th century: from obsolete French stolide or Latin stolidus (perhaps related to stultus ‘foolish’).

definitions.definition: calm, dependable, and showing little emotion or animation.
definitions.example: a stolid bourgeois gent

words.origin: late Middle English: from late Latin subjugat- ‘brought under a yoke’, from the verb subjugare, based on jugum ‘yoke’.

definitions.definition: bring under domination or control, especially by conquest.
definitions.example: the invaders had soon subjugated most of the population

words.origin: Middle English: from Old French, based on Latin super- ‘above, in excess’ + facere ‘do’.

definitions.definition: an excessive amount of something.
definitions.example: a surfeit of food and drink

definitions.definition: cause (someone) to desire no more of something as a result of having consumed or done it to excess.
definitions.example: I am surfeited with shopping

words.origin: late 16th century: alteration of obsolete swarty (see swart).

definitions.definition: dark-complexioned.
definitions.example: swarthy men with gleaming teeth

definitions.definition: relating to or along a tangent.
definitions.example: a tangential line

definitions.definition: diverging from a previous course or line; erratic.
definitions.example: tangential thoughts

words.origin: early 16th century (denoting one volume of a larger work): from French, via Latin from Greek tomos ‘section, roll of papyrus, volume’; related to temnein ‘to cut’.

definitions.definition: a book, especially a large, heavy, scholarly one.
definitions.example: a weighty tome

words.origin: early 19th century: said to be a contraction of toad-eater, a charlatan's assistant who ate toads; toads were regarded as poisonous, and the assistant's survival was thought to be due to the efficacy of the charlatan's remedy.

definitions.definition: a person who behaves obsequiously to someone important.
a pufferfish.
act in an obsequious way.
definitions.example: she imagined him toadying to his rich clients

words.origin: late Middle English: from Latin torpidus, from torpere ‘be numb or sluggish’.

definitions.definition: mentally or physically inactive; lethargic.
definitions.example: we sat around in a torpid state

definitions.definition: (at Oxford University) a series of races for eight-oared rowing boats held in Hilary term.
definitions.example: in my first year I rowed in Torpids

words.origin: mid 17th century (as an adjective in the sense ‘dressed to appear ridiculous’): from French travesti ‘disguised’, past participle of travestir, from Italian travestire, from trans- ‘across’ + vestire ‘clothe’.

definitions.definition: a false, absurd, or distorted representation of something.
definitions.example: the absurdly lenient sentence is a travesty of justice

definitions.definition: represent in a false, absurd, or distorted way.
definitions.example: Michael has betrayed the family by travestying them in his plays

words.origin: Middle English (in trenchant (sense 2)): from Old French, literally ‘cutting’, present participle of trenchier (see trench).

definitions.definition: vigorous or incisive in expression or style.
definitions.example: the White Paper makes trenchant criticisms of health authorities

definitions.definition: (of a weapon or tool) having a sharp edge.
definitions.example: a trenchant blade

words.origin: mid 16th century: from Latin tritus, past participle of terere ‘to rub’.

definitions.definition: (of a remark or idea) lacking originality or freshness; dull on account of overuse.
definitions.example: this point may now seem obvious and trite

words.origin: mid 16th century: from Latin truculentus, from trux, truc- ‘fierce’.

definitions.definition: eager or quick to argue or fight; aggressively defiant.
definitions.example: the truculent attitude of farmers to cheaper imports

words.origin: late 15th century: from French, or from Latin turpitudo, from turpis ‘disgraceful, base’.

definitions.definition: depraved or wicked behaviour or character.
definitions.example: acts of moral turpitude

words.origin: late Middle English (in umbrage (sense 2)): from Old French, from Latin umbra ‘shadow’. An early sense was ‘shadowy outline’, giving rise to ‘ground for suspicion’, whence the current notion of ‘offence’.

definitions.definition: offence or annoyance.
definitions.example: she took umbrage at his remarks

definitions.definition: shade or shadow, especially as cast by trees.

words.origin: late Old English upbrēdan  ‘allege (something) as a basis for censure’, based on braid in the obsolete sense ‘brandish’. The current sense dates from Middle English.

definitions.definition: find fault with (someone); scold.
definitions.example: he was upbraided for his slovenly appearance

definitions.definition: designed to be useful or practical rather than attractive.
definitions.example: a utilitarian building

definitions.definition: relating to or adhering to the doctrine of utilitarianism.
definitions.example: a utilitarian theorist

definitions.definition: an adherent of utilitarianism.

words.origin: early 17th century: from French véracité or medieval Latin veracitas, from verax ‘speaking truly’ (see veracious).

definitions.definition: conformity to facts; accuracy.
definitions.example: officials expressed doubts concerning the veracity of the story

words.origin: late Middle English: from French, from Latin vestigium ‘footprint’.

definitions.definition: a trace or remnant of something that is disappearing or no longer exists.
definitions.example: the last vestiges of colonialism

definitions.definition: a part or organ of an organism which has become reduced or functionless in the course of evolution.

words.origin: early 17th century (in the sense ‘alternation’): from French, or from Latin vicissitudo, from vicissim ‘by turns’, from vic- ‘turn, change’.

definitions.definition: a change of circumstances or fortune, typically one that is unwelcome or unpleasant.
definitions.example: her husband's sharp vicissitudes of fortune

definitions.definition: alternation between opposite or contrasting things.
definitions.example: the vicissitude of the seasons

words.origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘lower in value’): from late Latin vilificare, from Latin vilis ‘of low value’ (see vile).

definitions.definition: speak or write about in an abusively disparaging manner.
definitions.example: he has been vilified in the press

words.origin: early 17th century: from Italian, literally ‘learned, skilful’, from late Latin virtuosus (see virtuous).

definitions.definition: a person highly skilled in music or another artistic pursuit.
definitions.example: a celebrated clarinet virtuoso

definitions.definition: a person with a special knowledge of or interest in works of art or curios.
filled with bitter criticism or malice.
definitions.example: vitriolic attacks on the politicians

words.origin: mid 16th century: from Latin vituperat- ‘censured, disparaged’ (see vituperation).

definitions.definition: blame or insult (someone) in strong or violent language.
expressing or characterized by vehement opinions; loud and forceful.
definitions.example: he was a vociferous opponent of the takeover

words.origin: Middle English wantowen  ‘rebellious, lacking discipline’, from wan-  ‘badly’ + Old English togen  ‘trained’ (related to team and tow1).

definitions.definition: (of a cruel or violent action) deliberate and unprovoked.
definitions.example: sheer wanton vandalism

definitions.definition: sexually unrestrained or having many casual sexual relationships (typically used of a woman).
definitions.example: her cheeks burned as she recalled how forward she had been, how wanton

definitions.definition: growing profusely; luxuriant.
definitions.example: where wanton ivy twines

definitions.definition: a sexually unrestrained woman.
definitions.example: she'd behaved like a wanton

definitions.definition: play; frolic.
definitions.example: they sat gazing at the white-flecked pure blue sea and the various gulls that wantoned in the wake

definitions.definition: behave in a sexually unrestrained way.
definitions.example: women who have wantoned with suitors

words.origin: Old English wynsum, from wyn  ‘joy’ + -some1.

definitions.definition: attractive or appealing in a fresh, innocent way.
definitions.example: a winsome smile

words.origin: Old English geoc (noun), geocian (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch juk, German Joch, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin jugum and Greek zugon, also by Latin jungere ‘to join’.

definitions.definition: a wooden crosspiece that is fastened over the necks of two animals and attached to the plough or cart that they are to pull.
a part of a garment that fits over the shoulders and to which the main part of the garment is attached.
definitions.example: the pinafore fell amply from a short yoke

definitions.definition: a frame fitting over the neck and shoulders of a person, used for carrying pails or baskets.
the crossbar of a rudder.
a control lever in an aircraft.
put a yoke on (a pair of animals); couple or attach with or to a yoke.
definitions.example: a plough drawn by a camel and donkey yoked together

definitions.definition: attack, especially by strangling.
definitions.example: two crackheads yoked this girl

words.origin: late Old English zefferus, denoting a personification of the west wind, via Latin from Greek zephuros ‘(god of the) west wind’. Sense 1 dates from the late 17th century.

definitions.definition: a soft gentle breeze.
a fine cotton gingham.
skilled at gaining an advantage, especially deceitfully.
definitions.example: his wily opponents

words.origin: early 19th century: from French, literally ‘long speech’, from Italian tirata ‘volley’, from tirare ‘to pull’.

definitions.definition: a long, angry speech of criticism or accusation.
definitions.example: a tirade of abuse
